member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection
member.summary: Extension to providing advanced features including multi-file operations, asynchronous programming methods, visual design tools and support for SOCKS proxies.

remarks.para:
ExFTPConnection provides a range of advanced features that save development time and improve the quality of applications using FTP. These features include:
Multi-file operations: Methods such as and enable the developer to execute FTP operations on multiple files and directories with a single line of code.
Asynchronous methods: These are virtually essential when writing GUI application since they vastly improve responsiveness by executing time-consuming FTP operations in the background.
Visual design tools: ExFTPConnection integrates with Visual Studio and other IDEs to provide design-time tools that make FTP development easier. For example, the Connection Tester allows the developer to test their ExFTPConnection properties by connecting to an FTP server from within the development environment.
Proxy support: FTP operations may be performed through SOCKS4, SOCKS4A, SOCKS5 and HTTP proxies.

ExFTPConnection also provides the connectivity for our range of FTP Visual Controls, which are .NET GUI Controls that can be dropped onto Windows Forms to add sophisticated visual FTP application features with virtually no programming.

Multi-file Operations are methods that operate on multiple files. Operations that can be done of multiple files are:
Download of files matching a wildcard (see and ).
Download of files matching a user-defined (see and ).
Upload of files matching a wildcard (see and ).
Upload of files matching a user-defined (see and ).
Deletion of files matching a wildcard (see and ).
Deletion of files matching a user-defined (see and ).
Deletion of directory trees (see ).
FTP and FTPS (unlike SFTP) have certain characteristics that can sometimes cause problems when transferring a large number of files in a short time. ExFTPConnection can be configured to avoid these problems by means of the , and properties.

Each Begin___() method returns an reference, which may be cast to . FTPTask contains an identifier called , which uniquely identifies the method-call. Information about the task may also be obtained through this object. The task may be cancelled by calling the method with the given task ID.

When Concurrent transfers are multiple files may be transferred at the same time. This is achieved by maintaining a set of connections (called a "connection pool"). Each connection in the pool may transfer one file at a time, so the maximum number of files that may be transferred simultaneously is equal to the size of the pool (.

The Connection Tester may be used to assist with setting the properties of ExFTPConnection. It allows the developer to test various property-settings interactively without running their application. The Connection Tester may be accessed by (1) double-clicking on the component, (2) right-clicking on the component and selecting "Connection Designer" from the context menu, or (3) selecting the component and then clicking on the "Connection Tester" link at the bottom of the Properties View.
Proxy Settings may be controlled through the property.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection
member.summary: Provides FTP client functionality.

remarks.para: FTPConnection provides FTP client functionality. It is a .NET Component which may be used in visual designers, or it may be used as a conventional class.

Directory listings: Directory listings may be obtained in two basic forms: (1) The method returns strings containing file-names. (2) The method returns objects which contain information about the file including name, size, and date.

Downloading and uploading files: There are many different methods for downloading files from the server and uploading them to the server. Data may be copied from or to:
Files ( and
Streams ( and )
Byte-arrays ( and
Methods for downloading and uploading multiple files and directories are available in ExFTPConnection and SecureFTPConnection, which are included in
EDT's commercial .NET FTP products.

Other file operations: Other operations that may be performed on files are:
Renaming files using the method.
Deleting files using the method.
Getting a files size using the method and its modification time using the method.

Directories: The server maintains a "working directory" for each session. The path of the current working directory may be set and retrieved using the property. Changing directory to a subdirectory of the current working directory may be done by setting the same property, or by using the method. Changing up to a parent directory is done using the method. Empty directories may be removed using . If a non-empty directory is to be deleted then all the files and subdirectories in it must be deleted first. ExFTPConnection and SecureFTPConnection have methods for achieving this in a single method-call.

Events: FTPConnection fires events before and after most FTP operations. For example, before a file is downloaded the event is fired, while it's downloading the event is fired each time bytes have been transferred, and after it's been downloaded the event is fired. Operations that have corresponding events are:
FTP OperationEvents
Connecting and logging in , , , and
Closing and
Downloading data , and
Uploading data , and
Changing directories and
Deleting files/directories and
Sending FTP commands and

Logging: It is often very helpful to look at the detailed logging output if any problems are experienced communicating with FTP servers. All commands sent to the FTP server and subsequent replies are logged, and can be made available on the console or directed to a log file. Much other useful information is also logged.

Operations are logged at different levels, ranging from no logging (Off) to most verbose (All). Intermediate levels are Fatal, Error, Warning and Information.For example, if the overall level is set to Information, then Fatal, Error, Warning and Information log statements will be outputted, but Debug statements will not be logged.

The overall level can be set via the LogLevel property:
ftpConnection.LogLevel = LogLevel.Information;
The destination for logging can be set via several properties, described below:
PropertyDescription
LogToConsoleIf set to true, logging is directed to the console.
LogToTraceIf set to true, logging is directed to .NET's Trace facility.
LogFileIf to a valid filename, logging is directed to the file.
Overview of the FTP protocol: FTP is defined in the Request For Comments 959 document (RFC 959), which can be obtained from the Internet Engineering Task Force.

FTP requires a client program (FTP client) and a server program (FTP server). The FTP client can fetch files and file details from the server, and also upload files to the server. The server is generally loginPassword protected.

FTP commands are initiated by the FTP client, which opens a TCP connection called the control connection to the server. This control connection is used for the entire duration of a session between the FTP client and server. A session typically begins when the FTP client logs in, and ends when the quit command is sent to the server. The control connection is used exclusively for sending FTP commands and reading server replies - it is never used to transfer files.

Transient TCP connections called data connections are set up whenever data (normally a file's contents) is to be transferred. For example, the FTP client issues a command to retrieve a file from the server via the control channel. A data connection is then established, and the file's contents transferred to the FTP client across it. Once the transfer is complete, the data connection is closed. Meanwhile, the control connection is maintained.

Compliance: implements FTP as defined by RFC959. It attempts to match the standard as closely as possible, but due to variation in the level of compliance of the numerous FTP servers available, it sometime allows servers some tolerance. If the property is set to false then is more tolerant of non-compliant servers.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.ResumeTransfer
member.summary: Make the next file transfer (upload or download) resume.

remarks.para: For uploads, the bytes already transferred are skipped over, while for downloads, if writing to a file, it is opened in append mode, and only the bytes required are transferred.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.summary: Invokes the given site command on the server.

remarks.para: Site-specific commands are special commands that may be defined by a server. Such commands are defined on a server-by-server basis.

For example, a specific FTP server might define a PROCESS site-command which results in another piece of software on the server being directed to perform some sort of processing on a particular file. The command required might be:
In this case, the site-command would be invoked as follows:

member.param: Site-specific command to be invoked.

member.returns: The reply returned by the server.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.InvokeFTPCommand(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Invokes the given literal FTP command on the server.
member.remarks:
If a particular FTP command is not supported by , this method may sometimes be used to invoke the command. This will only work for simple commands that don't require special processing.
An example of an FTP command that could be invoked using this method is the FEAT command (which is actually behind the method. This would be done as follows:
string features = ftpConnection.InvokeFTPCommand("FEAT", "211");
The returned string could then be parsed to obtain the supported features of the server.
member.param: Command to be sent.
Valid return-codes (used for validating reply).
member.returns: The reply returned by the server.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.GetSize(System.String)
member.summary: Get the size of a remote file.
member.remarks: This is not a standard FTP command, it is defined in "Extensions to FTP", a draft RFC (draft-ietf-ftpext-mlst-16.txt).
member.param: Name or path of remote file in current working directory.
member.returns: Size of file in bytes.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.GetSize(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Get the size of a remote file, providing options on how errors are handled.
member.remarks: This is not a standard FTP command, it is defined in "Extensions to FTP", a draft RFC (draft-ietf-ftpext-mlst-16.txt). If throwOnError is true then an exception is thrown if there's an error, otherwise -1 is returned.
member.param: Name or path of remote file in current working directory.
If true then an exception is thrown if there's an error, otherwise -1 is returned.
member.returns: Size of file in bytes.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.Exists(System.String)
member.summary: Checks for the existence of a file on the server.

remarks.para: Not all servers support absolute paths, so it's safer to use relative paths. The path separator should be '/'. If problems are encountered the safest option is to change into the desired directory prior to calling this method and then supplying the name of the file without its path.
The existence of local files may be checked using the method.

member.param: Path of remote file.
member.returns: true if the named file exists on the server.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.DirectoryExists(System.String)
member.summary: Tests if the given directory exists.
member.remarks: The FTP protocol doesn't specify a standard way of testing for the existence of a directory, so this method tries to change into the directory and assumes that that the directory doesn't exist if an exception is thrown. The current working directory is restored before the method returns.
member.param: Name of directory
member.returns: true if directory exists and false otherwise

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.GetLastWriteTime(System.String)

member.param: Name of remote file.
member.returns: Last write time of file as a DateTime.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.GetLastWriteTime(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Get modification time for a remote file.
member.remarks: If throwOnError is true then an exception is thrown if there's an error, otherwise -1 is returned.
member.param: Name of remote file.
If true then an exception is thrown if there's an error, otherwise -1 is returned.
member.returns: Last write time of file as a DateTime.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.SetLastWriteTime(System.String,System.DateTime)
member.summary: Set modification time for a remote file.
member.remarks: Although times are passed to the server with second precision, some servers may ignore seconds and only provide minute precision. May not be supported by some FTP servers.
member.param: Name of remote file.
Desired write-time (given in local timezone).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.ParentControl
member.summary: Reference to Windows Forms controls (if available).

remarks.para: This property only applies to Windows Forms applications.

If the ParentControl property is set then all events and callbacks will be executed in the thread in which this control was created. If it is not set then FTPConnection will still attempt to find a control on whose thread events and callback will be executed. This prevents cross-thread errors.

member.summary: The assembly's build timestamp.
member.value: Timestamp of when the assembly was built in the format d-MMM-yyyy HH:mm:ss z.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.StrictReturnCodes
member.summary: Controls whether or not checking of return codes is strict.

remarks.para: Some servers return non-standard reply-codes. When this property is false only the first digit of the reply-code is checked, thus decreasing the sensitivity of edtFTPj to non-standard reply-codes. The default is true meaning that reply-codes must match exactly.

member.value: true if strict return code checking, false if non-strict.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.PublicIPAddress
member.summary: IP address of the client as the server sees it.
member.remarks: This property is necessary when using active mode in situations where the FTP client is behind a firewall.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.AutoPassiveIPSubstitution
member.summary: Use AutoPassiveIPSubstitution to ensure that data-socket connections are made to the same IP address that the control socket is connected to.

remarks.para: AutoPassiveIPSubstitution is useful in passive mode when the FTP server is supplying an incorrect IP address to the client for use in creating data connections (directory listings and file transfers), e.g. an internal IP address that is not accessible from the client. Instead, the client will use the IP address obtained from the FTP server's hostname.

This usually happens when an FTP server is behind a NAT router and has not been configured to reflect the fact that its internal (LAN) IP address is different from the address that external (Internet) machines connect to.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.ActivePortRange
member.summary: Specifies the range of ports to be used for data-channels in active mode.

remarks.para: By default, the operating system selects the ports to be used for active-mode data-channels. When ActivePortRange is defined, a port within this range will be selected.
This settings is not used in passive mode.
This can be particularly useful in scenarios where it is necessary to configure a NAT router to statically route a certain range of ports to the machine on which the FTP client is running.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.FileNotFoundMessages
member.summary: Holds fragments of server messages that indicate a file was not found
member.remarks: The fragments are used when it is necessary to examine the message returned by a server to see if it is saying a file was not found. If an FTP server is returning a different message that still clearly indicates a file was not found, use this property to add a new server fragment to the repository via the Add method. It would be helpful to email support at enterprisedt dot com to inform us of the message so it can be added to the next build.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.TransferCompleteMessages
member.summary: Holds fragments of server messages that indicate a transfer completed.
member.remarks: The fragments are used when it is necessary to examine the message returned by a server to see if it is saying a transfer completed. If an FTP server is returning a different message that still clearly indicates the transfer complete, use this property to add a new server fragment to the repository via the Add method. It would be helpful to email support at enterprisedt dot com to inform us of the message so it can be added to the next build.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.DirectoryEmptyMessages
member.summary: Holds fragments of server messages that indicate a directory is empty.
member.remarks: The fragments are used when it is necessary to examine the message returned by a server to see if it is saying a directory is empty, which is normally used by DirDetails. If an FTP server is returning a different message that still clearly indicates a directory is empty, use this property to add a new server fragment to the repository via the Add method. It would be helpful to email support at enterprisedt dot com to inform us of the message so it can be added to the next build.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.Timeout
member.summary: TCP timeout (in milliseconds) of the underlying sockets (0 means none).
TCP timeout (in milliseconds) of the underlying sockets (0 means none).
member.remarks: Timout value in milliseconds. The default value is 120000, which indicates a 120 second timeout period.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.TCPBufferSize
member.summary: TCP read/write buffer size of the underlying sockets (-1 means use defaults). For some transfers setting this value to 0 can improve performance.
member.remarks: The default value is -1, which means use the Microsoft defaults.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.ShowHiddenFiles
member.summary: Include hidden files in operations that involve listing of directories, and if supported by the server (FTP and FTPS).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.ConnectMode
member.summary: The connection-mode (passive or active) of data-channels.

remarks.para: When the connection-mode is active, the server will initiate connections to the FTP client, meaning that the FTP client must open a socket and wait for the server to connect to it. This often causes problems if the FTP client is behind a firewall.

When the connection-mode is passive, the FTP client will initiates connections to the server, meaning that the FTP client will connect to a particular socket on the server. This is generally used if the FTP client is behind a firewall.

member.summary: The server-side directory that the client is in immediately after connecting.
member.remarks: Prior to logging in the value is null. If the property was not set prior to connection then its value immediately after logging in will be the same as that of HomeDirectory.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.ServerDirectory
member.summary: The initial/current working directory on the server.
member.remarks: If the client is not currently connected, this is the initial working directory that will be changed to once the client connects.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.LocalDirectory
member.summary: The working directory on the local file-system into which files are downloaded.

remarks.para: LocalDirectory must be an absolute path, e.g. C:\work\ftp

LocalDirectory is specific to this component, i.e. changing it does not change the working directory of the application using this assembly. Files are downloaded into this directory if it is set and a relative path or no path is supplied as the destination filename.
LocalDirectory is null by default meaning that the application's normal working directory is used when downloading files.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.DeleteOnFailure
member.summary: Controls whether or not a file is deleted when a failure occurs.

remarks.para: If true, a partially downloaded file is deleted if there is a failure during the download. For example, the connection to the FTP server might have failed. If false, the partially downloaded file remains on the FTP client machine - and the download may be resumed, if it is a binary transfer.
By default this flag is set to true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.DataEncoding
member.summary: The character-encoding to use for transferring data in ASCII mode.

remarks.para: The default is to use the default character encoding (generally UTF8). Some common character encodings to try for western European languages are Windows-1252 and ISO-8859-1.
This encoding is not used when transferring data in binary mode.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.CommandEncoding
member.summary: The character-encoding to use for FTP control commands and when dealing with file- and directory-paths.

remarks.para: The default is ASCII, but should be changed when using file-names or directories containing non-ASCII characters.

Officially the FTP protocol (RFC959) only supports 7-bit ASCII characters. This means that file and directory names transferred across the control channel can only be ASCII. Fortunately, most servers actually support at least 8-bit ASCII. However there is no standard for what extended ASCII encoding is to be used. As a result, the meaning of characters 0 to 127 is well defined, but the meaning of characters 128 to 255 varies from one server to the other. One server might interpret character 193 as an accented A, whereas another might interpret it as an accented E.

By default, FTPConnection supports 7-bit ASCII. If it encounters a character whose code is 128 to 255 it will represent it as a question mark. This property allows the developer to select an 8-bit character encoding that matches that of the server. Unfortunately many servers do not state what 8-bit ASCII character set they are using, so it is often necessary to use trial and error to find out. Some common character encodings to try for western European languages are Windows-1252 and ISO-8859-1.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.SynchronizePassiveConnections
member.summary: For cases where the FTP server does not properly manage PASV connections, it may be necessary to synchronize the creation of passive data sockets. It has been reported that some FTP servers (such as those at Akamai) appear to get confused when multiple FTP clients from the same IP address attempt to connect at the same time (the server sends the same port number to multiple clients).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.FilePathEncoding
member.summary: The character-encoding to use when dealing with file- and directory-paths.
member.remarks: The default is ASCII, but should be changed when communicating with FTP servers that have file-names containing non-ASCII characters

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.ParsingCulture
member.summary: The culture for parsing file listings.

remarks.para: The method parses the file listings returned. The names of the file can contain a wide variety of characters, so it is sometimes necessary to set this property to match the character-set used on the server.
The default is Invariant Language (Invariant Country).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.TimeDifference
member.summary: [FTP/FTPS Only] Time difference between server and client (relative to client).
member.remarks: The time-difference is relative to the server such that, for example, if the server is in New York and the client is in London then the difference would be -5 hours (ignoring daylight savings differences). This property only applies to FTP and FTPS.

member.remarks: Some FTP and FTPS servers don't return file-modified times that include seconds. This flag indicates whether or not the most recent directory listing included seconds.

member.summary: The current file transfer type (BINARY or ASCII).
member.value: Transfer-type to be used for uploads and downloads.
member.remarks: When the transfer-type is set to BINARY then files are transferred byte-for-byte such that the transferred file will be identical to the original. When the transfer-type is set to ASCII then end-of-line characters will be translated where necessary between Windows and UNIX formats.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.AccountInfo
member.summary: Account information string.
member.value: The string supplied for use with the FTP ACCT command.

remarks.para: This property must be set before a connection with the server is made. It is used to supply optional information to the FTP server, and should only be set if it is known to be required.
Some proxy servers use this value for their proxy password.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.AutoLogin
member.summary: Determines if the component will automatically log in upon connection.

remarks.para: If this flag if true (the default) then the component will automatically attempt to log in when the method is called. The and (if required) properties should be set previously.
If the flag is false then the component will not log in until the method is called.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.AutoFeatures
member.summary: Determines if the component will automatically send the FEAT command.

remarks.para: If this flag if true then the component will automatically send the FEAT command after logging in when the method is called. This is used to detect if UTF-8 is supported, amongst other things.
If the flag is false (the default) then the component will not send the FEAT command after logging in.
The default has been changed to false because on some FTP servers, calling FEAT affects the state of the server - there are problems creating passive sockets for listings and transfers.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.EventsEnabled
member.summary: Determines whether or not events are currently enabled.
member.value: The EventsEnabled flag determines whether or not events are currently enabled. If the flag is true (the default) then events will fire as appropriate. If the flag is false then no events will be fired by this object.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.UseGuiThreadIfAvailable
member.summary: Determines whether or not event-handlers will be run on the GUI thread if one is available.
member.value: The UseGuiThreadIfAvailable flag determines whether or not event-handlers will be run on the GUI thread if one is available. If the flag is true (the default) then they will be run on the GUI thread if one is available (only for Windows Forms applications). If the flag is false then they will be run on a worker-thread.
member.remarks: It is important to note that if event-handlers are run on a worker-thread then Windows Forms related operations will usually fail. Since such operations are commonly used in event-handlers, the default is true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnection.LogLevel

This method wraps so setting either is equivalent to setting the other.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.Connect
member.summary: Connect to the FTP server and (if is set) log into the server.

remarks.para: If this component is being used on a form or within another component then it is a good idea to use the "Connection Tester" to test the property settings.
Connections are not opened until the method is called. Connection-, Authentication-, and Security-related properties should be set prior to opening the connection.

At a minimum, the following properties should be set prior to connection.
Property Description
Protocol The protocol to use: SFTP, explicit FTPS, implicit FTPS or plain FTP.
ServerAddress The domain-name or IP-address of the server.
UserName User-name of account on the server.
Password Password of account on the server.
If is true then the component will attempt to log in immediately after successfully connecting.
This method will throw an FTPException if the component is already connected to the server.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.PostLogin
member.summary: Called after the user has been successfully logged in.
member.remarks: Sets the transfer-type and the current working directory. If AutoLogin is set to false, this method should be called explicitly to initialise the client state.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.PerformAutoLogin
member.summary: Attempt to log into the server if is on.
member.remarks: A login attempt will take place only if the property and (optionally) the property have been set.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.AbortAsynchronous(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Aborts all queued asynchronous operations.
member.remarks: This method clears the queue of pending asynchronous operations (i.e. those initiated using the BeginXXX methods). If interruptCurrent is true then any transfer currently being performed is cancelled.
member.param: Causes any current transfer to be cancelled.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.Close(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Quit the FTP session.
member.remarks: If abruptClose is true then the session will be closed immediately by closing the control socket without sending the QUIT command, otherwise the session will be closed by sending a QUIT command before closing the socket.
member.param: Closes session abruptly (see comments).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.BeginConnect(System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Begins an asynchronous request to connect to an FTP server.

remarks.para: You can create a callback method that implements the delegate and pass its name to the BeginConnect method. The state argument may be used to pass in data that will be passed to the callback method.
For more information please refer to the synchronous version of this method, .

member.param: The delegate.
An object that contains state information for this request.
member.returns: An that references the asynchronous connection.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.EndConnect(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Completes the asynchronous operation started in .

remarks.para: Before calling , you need to create a callback method that implements the delegate. This callback method executes in a separate thread and is called by the system after returns. The callback method must accept the returned by the method as a parameter. This parameter may then be passed to the EndConnect method to complete the operation.

member.param: An that stores state information for this asynchronous operation.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ResumeTransfer
member.summary: Make the next file transfer (upload or download) resume.

remarks.para: For uploads, the bytes already transferred are skipped over, while for downloads, if writing to a file, it is opened in append mode, and only the bytes required are transferred.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ResumeNextTransfer
member.summary: Make the next file transfer (upload or download) resume.

remarks.para: For uploads, the bytes already transferred are skipped over, while for downloads, if writing to a file, it is opened in append mode, and only the bytes required are transferred.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ResumeNextDownload(System.Int64)
member.summary: Make the next download resume at a specific point.

remarks.para: This resume method allows the resume offset to be set explicitly for downloads. Offset bytes are skipped before downloading the file.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).
If the next transfer is an upload, this setting is cancelled.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.CancelTransfer
member.summary: Cancels the current transfer.

remarks.para: This method is generally called from a separate thread. Note that this may leave partially written files on the server or on local disk, and should not be used unless absolutely necessary. The server is not notified.
Any asynchronous transfers currently queued cancelled also.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.CancelTask(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Cancels the given asynchronous task.

remarks.para: The task will always be removed if it isn't currently executing. If the task is currently executing then it can only be cancelled if it is a file-transfer or a directory-listing.

member.param: Task to be cancelled. Pass in the object returned by a connection's BeginXYZ() method.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.CancelTask(System.Int32)
member.summary: Cancels the asynchronous task with the given ID.

remarks.para: The task will always be removed if it isn't currently executing. If the task is currently executing then it can only be cancelled if it is a file-transfer or a directory-listing.

member.param: ID of task to be cancelled. Pass in the object returned by a connection's BeginXYZ() method.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.TransferFileFXP(EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Transfer a file between FTP servers using FXP.

remarks.para: For this to succeed, both FTP servers must have FXP enabled. The source (which is this connection's server) and destination FTPClients must already be connected to their FTP servers when this method is called.
The file will be transferred in whatever mode is currently set, i.e. BINARY or ASCII.
The file must be in the current working directory of the source, and will be placed in the current working directory of the destination.

member.param: Connection to the destination server.
name of file on source server to transfer
name of file to be written to destination server

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.UploadStream(System.IO.Stream,System.String)
member.summary: Upload a stream of data to the FTP server in the current working directory.

remarks.para: The stream is closed after the transfer is complete if is true (the default) and are left open otherwise. If the stream is left open the its position will be at the end of the stream. Use to change the position if required.

para.example: The following example uploads the contents of a to the server and downloads the same file into another MemoryStream:

member.param: Input stream of data to put.
Name of remote file in current working directory.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.UploadByteArray(System.Byte[],System.String)
member.summary: Upload an array of bytes to the FTP server in the current working directory.

para.example: The following example uploads the string "Hello world" to the server into a file called helloworld.txt:

member.param: Array of bytes to put.
Name of remote file in current working directory.

member.remarks: The stream is closed after the transfer is complete if is true (the default) and are left open otherwise.

member.summary: Uploads the local directory (and its subdirectories) to the remote directory.

remarks.para: The remote directory will be created if it doesn't already exist.
should be used if more control over which files are transferred is required.

member.param: Local directory
Remote directory (will be created if it doesn't already exist)

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.UploadMultiple(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Put multiple files from the specified local directory into the current remote directory.

remarks.para: Wildcard expression use '?' to match any single character and '*' to match multiple characters. For example, "file*.txt" will match any file-name starting with "file" and having an extension ".txt".
Note that if the LocalDirectory property is set and localDirectory is a relative path, it will be combined with the LocalDirectory to find the target directory.

member.param: local directory to get files from
wildcard for specifying files (? for single characters and * for multiple characters)

remarks.para: Before calling BeginUploadFile, you need to create a callback method that implements the delegate. This callback method executes in a separate thread and is called by the system after BeginUploadFile returns. The callback method must accept the returned by the BeginUploadFile method as a parameter. This parameter may then be passed to the EndUploadFile method to complete the operation.

member.param: An that stores state information for this asynchronous operation.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.Synchronize(System.String,System.String,EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules)
member.summary: Synchronizes the given local directory with the given remote directory according to the given synchronization rules.

remarks.para: Synchronization aims to ensure that the files in a directory on the local machine match those in a directory on the remote machine.

The instructions contained in inform the synchronization process how files should be matched. If these rules are insufficient then the event may be used to provide customized logic for matching files.
The and events are triggered before and after the synchronization operation is performed, respectively.

member.param: Directory on the local machine to synchronize. If this argument is null then will be used.
Directory on the server to synchronize. If this argument is null then will be used.
Rules to apply to the synchronization operation. If this argument is null then will be used.
member.returns: containing results of synchronization operation

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.InvokeSiteCommand(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Invokes the given site command on the server.

remarks.para: Site-specific commands are special commands that may be defined by a server. Such commands are defined on a server-by-server basis.

For example, a specific FTP server might define a PROCESS site-command which results in another piece of software on the server being directed to perform some sort of processing on a particular file. The command required might be:
In this case, the site-command would be invoked as follows:

member.param: Site-specific command to be invoked.
Arguments of the command to be invoked.
member.returns: The reply returned by the server.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.InvokeFTPCommand(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Invokes the given literal FTP command on the server.
member.remarks:
If a particular FTP command is not supported by , this method may sometimes be used to invoke the command. This will only work for simple commands that don't require special processing.
An example of an FTP command that could be invoked using this method is the FEAT command (which is actually behind the method. This would be done as follows:
string features = ftpConnection.InvokeFTPCommand("FEAT", "211");
The returned string could then be parsed to obtain the supported features of the server.
member.param: Command to be sent.
Valid return-codes (used for validating reply).
member.returns: The reply returned by the server.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.GetSize(System.String)
member.summary: Get the size of a remote file.
member.remarks: This is not a standard FTP command, it is defined in "Extensions to FTP", a draft RFC (draft-ietf-ftpext-mlst-16.txt).
member.param: Name or path of remote file in current working directory.
member.returns: Size of file in bytes.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.Exists(System.String)
member.summary: Checks for the existence of a file on the server.

remarks.para: Not all servers support absolute paths, so it's safer to use relative paths. The path separator should be '/'. If problems are encountered the safest option is to change into the desired directory prior to calling this method and then supplying the name of the file without its path.
The existence of local files may be checked using the method.

member.param: Path of remote file.
member.returns: true if the named file exists on the server.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.DirectoryExists(System.String)
member.summary: Tests if the given directory exists.
member.remarks: The FTP protocol doesn't specify a standard way of testing for the existence of a directory, so this method tries to change into the directory and assumes that that the directory doesn't exist if an exception is thrown. The current working directory is restored before the method returns.
member.param: Name of directory
member.returns: true if directory exists and false otherwise

member.summary: Get modification time for a remote file.
member.param: Name of remote file.
member.returns: Last write time of file as a DateTime.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.Protocol
member.summary: Type of file transfer to use.
member.remarks:
edtFTPnet/Express offers two types of non-secure file transfer, FTP and HTTP. Secure file transfer protocols are available in edtFTPnet/PRO:
Type
FTP Traditional unencrypted FTP.
FTPSExplicit FTP-over-SSL which allows switching between secure and unsecure transfers. edtFTPnet/PRO only.
FTPSImplicit FTP-over-SSL which simply performs FTP over pure SSL sockets. edtFTPnet/PRO only.
SFTP SSH File Transfer Protocol. edtFTPnet/PRO only.
HTTP HTTP File Transfers. Currently, only downloads can be performed.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.Timeout
member.summary: TCP timeout (in milliseconds) of the underlying sockets (0 means none).
member.remarks: Timout value in milliseconds. The default value is 120000, which indicates a 120 second timeout period.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.TransferBufferSize
member.summary: The size of the application buffers used in reading and writing data.

remarks.para: The size of receive and transmit buffers. The default is 32700.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.CloseStreamsAfterTransfer
member.summary: Determines if transfer-methods taking s as arguments should close the stream once the transfer is completed.
member.remarks: If CloseStreamsAfterTransfer is true (the default) then streams are closed after a transfer has completed, otherwise they are left open.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.TransferNotifyInterval
member.summary: The number of bytes transferred between each notification of the event.

remarks.para: This property determines the approximate number of bytes transferred between each event.
The default value is 4096.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.TransferNotifyListings
member.summary: By default the event is not triggered during directory listings - this property can be used to enable this behaviour.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.IntegrityCheckTransfers
member.summary: Control integrity checking after file transfers.

remarks.para: Some FTP servers support the XCRC command, permitting a checksum to be calculated after transferring a file to ensure it transferred correctly.

If this flag is switched on, CRC checks will be attempted for binary transfers. An exception will be thrown if CRC checks are not supported by the server. Also, integrity checks cannot be performed for appends.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ForceConnectModeExtensions
member.summary: Force the use of EPRT and EPSV extensions even for IPv4

remarks.para: The IPv6 EPRT and EPSV commands are supported, but by default only used for IPv6. They can, however be used for IPv4, and will be if this flag is set to true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.CompressionPreferred
member.summary: Flag to enable or disable MODE Z compression for FTP/FTPS transfers.

remarks.para: Some FTP servers support the MODE Z command, permitting transfers to be compressed. This speeds up transfers significantly for files that are compressible such as text files.

If this flag is switched on, MODE Z compression is enabled if the server permits it. If the flag is later switched off, MODE Z compression is not disabled until the connection is closed and then re-opened again.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.DataEncoding
member.summary: The character-encoding to use for transferring data in ASCII mode.

remarks.para: The default is to use the default character encoding (generally UTF8). Some common character encodings to try for western European languages are Windows-1252 and ISO-8859-1.
This encoding is not used when transferring data in binary mode.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ServerAddress
member.summary: The domain-name or IP address of the FTP server.

remarks.para: This property may only be set if not currently connected.

para.example: The following example illustrates an SFTP client connecting to a server:

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ServerPort
member.summary: The port on the server to which to connect the control-channel.

remarks.para: This property may only be set if not currently connected.

para.example: The following example illustrates an SFTP client connecting to a server:

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.DeleteOnFailure
member.summary: Controls whether or not a file is deleted when a failure occurs.

remarks.para: If true, a partially downloaded file is deleted if there is a failure during the download. For example, the connection to the FTP server might have failed. If false, the partially downloaded file remains on the FTP client machine - and the download may be resumed, if it is a binary transfer.
By default this flag is set to true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.UserName
member.summary: User-name of account on the server.
member.value: The user-name of the account the server that will be logged into upon connection.

remarks.para: This property must be set before a connection with the server is made.

para.example: The following example illustrates an FTP client connecting to a server:

member.value: The password of the account the FTP server that will be logged into upon connection.

remarks.para: This property must be set before a connection with the server is made.

para.example: The following example illustrates an FTP client connecting to a server:

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.IsTransferring
member.summary: Indicates whether or not a synchronous or asynchronous transfer is currently under way.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.CommandEncoding
member.summary: The character-encoding to use when dealing with file- and directory-paths.
member.remarks: The default is ASCII, but should be changed when communicating with FTP servers that have file-names containing non-ASCII characters

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.MultiTransferSleepEnabled
member.summary: Determines whether or not "sleeping" is enabled during multiple FTP/FTPS data transfers.

remarks.para: FTP/FTPS uses a separate TCP connection for each data transfer (i.e. upload, download, or directory listing). TCP ports go into a TIME_WAIT state for a number of seconds after each connection, making it unusable for this period. This means that it is possible to run out of TCP ports when multiple files are transferred in a short period of time.
Periodic sleeping can reduce this problem. When enabled through the property, the connection will wait for seconds each time files have been transferred via multiple-transfer operations.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.MultiTransferCountBeforeSleep
member.summary: Number of transfers before "sleeping" during multiple FTP/FTPS data transfers.

remarks.para: FTP/FTPS uses a separate TCP connection for each data transfer (i.e. upload, download, or directory listing). TCP ports go into a TIME_WAIT state for a number of seconds after each connection, making it unusable for this period. This means that it is possible to run out of TCP ports when multiple files are transferred in a short period of time.
Periodic sleeping can reduce this problem. When enabled through the property, the connection will wait for seconds each time files have been transferred via multiple-transfer operations.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.MultiTransferSleepTime
member.summary: Number of seconds spent "sleeping" during multiple FTP/FTPS data transfers.

remarks.para: FTP/FTPS uses a separate TCP connection for each data transfer (i.e. upload, download, or directory listing). TCP ports go into a TIME_WAIT state for a number of seconds after each connection, making it unusable for this period. This means that it is possible to run out of TCP ports when multiple files are transferred in a short period of time.
Periodic sleeping can reduce this problem. When enabled through the property, the connection will wait for seconds each time files have been transferred via multiple-transfer operations.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.DetectTransferMode
member.summary: Determines whether the transfer mode in operations involving multiple files is automatically changed between ASCII and binary as appropriate.
member.remarks: See for instructions on how to register a file extension as ASCII, and for how to obtain the current registered extensions.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.SocksProxySettings
member.summary: Settings for SOCKS proxy.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ProxySettings
member.summary: Settings for using proxies.

remarks.para: Proxies may be used for FTPing through firewalls. HTTP and SOCKS (4,4A and 4) are supported.

SOCKS supports both passive (PASV) and active (PORT) mode transfers. Note that only passive mode transfers are possible via an HTTP proxy. There is no facility for HTTP proxies to listen for incoming connections, and hence active mode transfers cannot be done via an HTTP proxy. An exception will be thrown if they are attempted.
Often a username and password will be required to authenticate with the proxy. These can be set in ProxySettings.
ProxySettings is easiest to edit via the Property View.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.KeepAliveTransfer
member.summary: Flag to enable the use of keep alive messages during data transfers.
member.remarks: During very large transfers some servers timeout, meaning that the transfer is not correctly completed. Most servers can't cope with keep alives being sent during a transfer, so only set this property if you are having timeout problems with very large transfers, and you can't increase the timeout on the server. Use with caution - this may cause messages to arrive out of order. Note that the property is used to set the interval between keep alives.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.KeepAliveIdle
member.summary: Flag to enable the use of keep alive messages, which are sent to keep the connection alive when no activity is occurring.
member.remarks: The client only contacts the server during periods of inactivity.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.KeepAlivePeriodSecs
member.summary: Period (in seconds) at which the client contacts the server so that the connection doesn't time out.
member.remarks: The client only contacts the server during periods of inactivity (), or during transfers if is set.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.DefaultSyncRules
member.summary: Rules that are used during synchronization operations when no other rules are specified.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.RetryCount
member.summary: Number of times to retry a failing file-transfer before giving up.

remarks.para: If this value is greater than zero then file-transfer operations will be retried if the given number of times. If the operation has been retried RetryCount times without success then an exception will be thrown.
A delay of milliseconds will separate consecutive retries.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.RetryDelay
member.summary: Milliseconds to wait for before retrying a failing file-transfer (if RetryCount>0).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.MaxTransferRate
member.summary: The maximum transfer rate in bytes per sec. Set to -1 or 0 to indicate no limiting should be applied.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ConcurrentTransferSettings
member.summary: Settings for concurrent transfers. Off by default.

remarks.para: The concurrent transfer feature of ExFTPConnection and can greatly speed up transfers. This performance is achieved by making several connections to the server at the same time, and using them such that more than one file may be transferred at the same time. For example, if a maximum of 4 connections (see is set then up to 4 files may be transferred simultaneously.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.CacheListings
member.summary: Cache directory listings.
member.remarks: If this property true then directory listings will be cached between accesses. This can greatly speed up calls to and . The directory cache may be cleared at any time by calling .

member.summary: For cases where your FTP server does not properly manage PASV connections, it may be necessary to synchronize the creation of passive data sockets. It has been reported that some FTP servers (such as those at Akamai) appear to get confused when multiple FTP clients from the same IP address attempt to connect at the same time. The default value for SynchronizePassiveConnections is false.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPControlSocket.AutoPassiveIPSubstitution
member.summary: Use AutoPassiveIPSubstitution to ensure that data-socket connections are made to the same IP address that the control socket is connected to.
member.remarks: AutoPassiveIPSubstitution can be useful when connecting to FTP servers that request data connections be connected to an IP address other than the one to which the connection was initially made. This usually happens when an FTP server is behind a NAT router and has not been configured to reflect the fact that its internal (LAN) IP address is different from the address that external (Internet) machines connect to.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PortRange
member.summary: Specifies a TCP port range defining the lower and upper limits for data-channels.
member.remarks: The default is to let the operating system select the port number within the range 1024-5000. If the range is set to anything other than the default then ports will be selected sequentially, increasing by one until the higher limit is reached and then wrapping around to the lower limit.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PortRange.LowPort
member.summary: Lowest port number in range.
member.remarks: The default value is 1024. If it is left at this value and is left at 5000 then the OS will select the port. If it is set to anything other than 1024 then ports will be selected sequentially, increasing by one until the higher limit is reached and then wrapping around to the lower limit.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PortRange.HighPort
member.summary: Highest port number in range.
member.remarks: The default value is 5000. If it is left at this value and is left at 1024 then the OS will select the port. If it is set to anything other than 5000 then ports will be selected sequentially, increasing by one until the higher limit is reached and then wrapping around to the lower limit.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PortRange.UseOSAssignment
member.summary: Determines if the operating system should select the ports within the range 1024-5000.
member.remarks: If UseOSAssignment is set to true then the OS will select data-channel ports within the range 1024-5000. Otherwise ports will be selected sequentially, increasing by one until the higher limit is reached and then wrapping around to the lower limit. Setting this flag will cause and to be set to 1024 and 5000, respectively.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PortRange.PropertyChangeHandler
member.summary: Called when a property is changed.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnectMode
member.summary: Enumerates the connect modes that are possible, active and passive.
member.remarks: The mode describes the behaviour of the server. In active mode, the server actively connects to the client to establish a data connection. In passive mode the client connects to the server.

member.summary: Represents active - PORT - connect mode. The server connects to the client for data transfers.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnectMode.PASV
member.summary: Represents passive - PASV - connect mode. The client connects to the server for data transfers.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileTransferEventArgs.FileSize
member.summary: Size of remote file (see remarks)

remarks.para: This property has been supercede by and , to reflect the fact that the local and remote file-sizes may be different when transferring in ASCII mode.
Some servers do not support the command required to get the size of a particular file. In this case, or in case of an error, the FileSize property will be -1.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileTransferEventArgs.LocalFileSize
member.summary: Size of local file (see remarks).
member.remarks: For binary transfers this is the same as the size of the remove file , but for ASCII transfers it may differ.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileTransferEventArgs.RemoteFileSize
member.summary: Size of remote file (see remarks)

remarks.para: For the and events, the value of this property will be the size of the local file, since it is not yet known what size ASCII files will be once uploaded to the server.
Some servers do not support the command required to get the size of a particular file. In this case, or in case of an error, the FileSize property will be -1.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileTransferEventArgs.BytesTransferred
member.summary: Number of bytes transferred.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileTransferEventArgs.LastWriteTime
member.summary: Last write-time of the file.
member.remarks: For all events, except the event, this property returns the timestamp of the remote file. For the timestamp of the local file is provided.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileTransferEventArgs.Cancel
member.summary: Cancel transfer.

remarks.para: For and this flag may be set to false if the operation is to be aborted. For and this flag indicates if the operation was aborted.
Note that multiple file transfers cannot be cancelled.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileSystemWatcher
member.summary: Raises events when files in the current remote directory are created, changed or deleted.

remarks.para: FTPFileSystemWatcher listens to events and (optionally) polls the FTP server every to detect changes.

Three events are provided for notification of changes on the remote file:
Event Triggered when FTPFileSystemWatcher detects that..
...a file has been created on the server.
...a file has been created on or uploaded to the server.
...a file has been deleted on the server.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileSystemWatcher.DirectoryPollingEnabled
member.summary: Determines whether or not the server directory should be fetched periodically.

remarks.para: If enabled the server will be polled every seconds to detect changes that are not made via the current instance. If no such changes are expected then this is not necessary since changes made through the current will be detected by means of event-handlers.

remarks.para: Note that this property will only be used if is true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileSystemWatcher.DelayPeriodSecs
member.summary: Number of seconds to wait after a connection is established or the current directory is changed before requesting a directory listing.
member.remarks: This property is used to reduce the chance of requesting redundant directory listings. For example, other FTP GUI controls will often request a directory listing after changing directories, so an additional request from FTPFileSystemWatcher would be redundant.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules
member.summary: Contains a set of instructions for how a synchronization operation should be performed.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.Direction
member.summary: Controls the direction of synchronization.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.IgnoreCase
member.summary: Determines whether or not case is ignored when matching file-names.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.IncludeFilesInFilter
member.summary: Controls whether the filter is an inclusion-filter or an exclusion-filter.
member.remarks: If IncludeFilesInFilter is true (the default) then only the files that match the filter (if there is one) will be synchronized. Otherwise only those that don't match it will be synchronized.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.FilterType
member.summary: Controls whether the should be interpreted as a wildcard string or a regular expression.
member.remarks: Wildcard strings use a DOS-like notation where ? matches any single character and * matches multiple characters. Regular expressions are of the kind used in .

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.FilterOnServer
member.summary: Controls whether files are filtered on the client (the default) or on the server. Requires server to support filtering.
member.remarks: When set to true filters will be passed to the server such that only files that match the filter are returned to the client in directory listings. This can be more efficient since smaller listings may be returned, but it requires the server to support filtering (wildcards or regular-expressions).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.FileNameFilter
member.summary: File-name filter that controls which files are synchronized.
member.remarks: FileNameFilter may contain multiple strings separated by commas. Each string may be a regular expression (as defined by ) or a wildcard string (where ? matches any single character and * matches multiple characters). The type of filter (wildcard or regular expression) may be chosen via the property. The filter may be used to exclude or include files; this behavior is selected via the property. By default files in the filter are included. If no filter is defined then all files will be considered.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.FilterCallback
member.summary: FileFilter callback to be called each time a file is to be filtered.
member.remarks: If is set to then this will be called when a file is to be filtered.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.IgnoreDate
member.summary: Controls whether or not dates are taken into consideration when performing file comparisons.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.TransferAlways
member.summary: Causes files to be transferred regardless of date and size.
member.remarks: This flag overrides all other flags except .

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.TransferNewOnly
member.summary: If TransferNewOnly is set then only files that do not exist on the target file-system will be considered.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.TransferMatchingOnly
member.summary: If TransferMatchingOnly is set then only files that exist both on the source and target file-systems will be considered.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.DeleteIfSourceAbsent
member.summary: When set, this flag will advise that if a file exists on the target but not on the source then that file should be deleted.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.SyncLocalDateAfterDownload
member.summary: When set, this flag will cause the control to set the date of the local file to be the same as the remote file after the file has been downloaded.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.IncludeSubdirectories
member.summary: When set, this flag will cause files in subdirectories to be included in the synchronization operaton.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.StopOnError
member.summary: When set, this flag will cause synchronization to stop when errors occur.
member.remarks: If StopOnError is true (the default) the synchronization process will stop when an error occurs. If StopOnError is false then will continue the process as far as it can. For example, if an attempt to create a directory fails then it will give up on transferring files in that directory, but will keep transferring other files.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules.FileRegEx
member.summary: Returns an array of regular expression that match the wildcards.

member.summary: Determines whether or not the main connection will be included in the pool of connections that is used for concurrent transfers.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PoolMode.UseMainConnection
member.summary: The main connection will be included in the pool.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PoolMode.ReserveMainConnection
member.summary: The main connection will be excluded from the pool.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PoolMode.Automatic
member.summary: The component will automatically determine the most appropriate mode.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings
member.summary: Settings for controlling concurrent transfers.

remarks.para: When concurrent transfers are (and ) will maintain a pool of up to MaxConnections-1 'slave' connections in addition to its own 'main' connection. Many servers limit the number of connections a single client may make to the server, so the number of active connections may be less than .

Interactive applications, such as traditional FTP client apps, can benefit from reserving one connection for user-actions, such as fetching directory listings. Thus when is set to the main connection will not usually be used for transfers. This is not an issue in non-interactive applications in which case the PoolMode may be set to . The default value of PoolMode is where the main connection will used if is not null.

Although it's generally desirable to reserve the main connection for user interactivity in FTP client-type applications, this cannot be done if the server only permits one connection to the server. If is set to true (the default) then the main connection will be used for transfers if it is the only possible connection to the server.
If AutoRequeue is enabled then a task that has been given a failed connection will automatically be requeued if at least one connection is still operational.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.OnPropertyChanged(System.String)
member.summary: Called when a property has been changed.
member.param: Name of property.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.Enabled
member.summary: Determines whether or not concurrent transfers enabled.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.PoolMode
member.summary: Controls whether or not the main connection is included in the pool.
member.remarks: Concurrent transfers are executed on a set of connections called a "pool". This set of connections is maintained alongside the main (or ) object. If PoolMode is then the main connection will be included in the pool and therefore made available for concurrent transfers. This is often not desirable in GUI applications where it's desirable to keep a connection available for servicing user-actions, such as listing directories; in these cases PoolMode should be set to . If the PoolMode is set to to (the default) then the component will automatically try to determine the most appropriate mode.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.MaxConnections
member.summary: Maximum number of connections to the server.

remarks.para: When concurrent transfers are (and ) will maintain a pool of up to MaxConnections-1 'slave' connections in addition to its own 'main' connection. Many servers limit the number of connections a single client may make to the server, so the number of active connections may be less than MaxConnections.

Interactive applications, such as classic FTP client apps, can benefit from reserving one connection for user-actions, such as fetching directory listings. Thus when is set to the main connection will not usually be used for transfers. This is not an issue in non-interactive applications in which case the PoolMode may be set to . The default value of PoolMode is where the main connection will used if is not null.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.AutoRequeue
member.summary: Automatically requeue tasks on connection-failure.
member.remarks: If AutoRequeue is enabled then a task that has been given a failed connection will automatically be requeued if at least one connection is still operational.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.FallBackToMainConnection
member.summary: Should the main connection be used if all connections in the pool fail?
member.remarks: Some servers allow only one connection per user. In these cases concurrent transfers are not possible. If, however, concurrent transfers have been enabled and the main connection is not included in the pool (i.e. is ), then transfers will fail because no additional connections could be made. In these cases, the main connection may be used as a fallback by having FallBackToMainConnection set to true (the default). This has the potentially undesirable effect of tying up the main connection while files are being transferred, thus making it unavailable for other operations, such as listing directories. In GUI applications, this will result in a less responsive interface.

member.name: E:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.PropertyChanged
member.summary: Occurs when a property is changed.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPTransferType.ASCII
member.summary: Represents ASCII transfer type. As data is transferred, line terminator characters are translated into the local (client) platform's line terminator characters (CRLF for Windows platforms). For example, if transferring text files from a Unix server, line terminators will be converted from LF to CRLF.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPTransferType.BINARY
member.summary: Represents Image (or binary) transfer type. Files are transferred byte for byte without any conversion.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection
member.summary: Extends 's features by providing support for all secure file-transfer protocols, i.e. SFTP, explicit FTPS and implicit FTPS.

remarks.para: Connections are not opened until the method is called. Connection-, Authentication-, and Security-related properties should be set prior to opening the connection.

At a minimum, the following properties must be set prior to connection.
Property Description
Protocol The protocol to use: SFTP, explicit FTPS, implicit FTPS or plain FTP.
ServerAddress The domain-name or IP-address of the server.
UserName User-name of account on the server.
Password Password of account on the server.

The Connection Tester may be used to assist with setting these and other properties. It allows the developer to test various property-settings interactively without running their application. The Connection Designer may be accessed by (1) double-clicking on the component, (2) right-clicking on the component and selecting "Connection Tester" from the context menu, or (3) selecting the component and then clicking on the "Connection Tester" link at the bottom of the Properties View.

Secure Transfers are enabled through the Security properties. At a minimum, the Protocol should be set to SFTP, FTPSExplicit or FTPSImplicit representing the SSH File Transfer Protocol, explicit FTP over SSL, and implicit FTP over SSL, respectively. The issue of Server Validation must also be addressed.

Server Validation is the process of making sure that the server with which the client is communicating is indeed the intended server. While developing code, this process may be disabled by setting to , which disables server validation and thus postpones any complications related to it, but this should not be done in deployed applications.
To achieve server validation, the property may be set to or . The method by which a server is validated depends on whether the protocol is SSH-based or SSL-based.

In the SSL-based protocols, explicit FTPS and implicit FTPS, a certificate that is able to verify the FTP server must be installed on the machine on which the FTP client software is running. This certificate may be either the certificate of the server itself, or the certificate of the Certificate Authority (CA). SecureFTPConnection provides various means of installing server certificates:
Design-Time The Certificate Manager GUI may be displayed at design-time by (1) right-clicking on the component and selecting "Certificate Manager" from the context menu, or (2) selecting the component and then clicking on the "Certificate Manager" link at the bottom of the Properties View.
Runtime GUI The Certificate Manager GUI may be displayed at runtime by using the method.
Runtime Programmatic Certificates may be imported into the operating system's Certificate Stores using the Import methods of .
Microsoft Management Console (MMC) The Microsoft Management Controls (MMC) may be used for managing the operating system's certificate stores.

In the SSH-based protocol, SFTP, the server is validated by means of its public key. Typically, the server's public key is stored in either a file containing that single key, or in a file often called known_hosts which can contain a number of public keys for different servers. When the client connects to the server, the server's public key is returned and compared with the available public keys stored in the client. Known-host files may be loaded by setting the KnownHosts.KnownHostsFile property. Individual public keys may be loaded using the KnownHosts.AddKnownHost method.

Client validation is the process by which the client authenticates itself to the server. For many FTP/FTPS/SFTP servers password authentication is sufficient; it is configured through the and properties. In explicit FTPS and implicit FTPS, a certificate may also be required; this loaded by the property. In SFTP the server may request the public key corresponding to the client's private key, which is set using the property.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.Connect
member.summary: Connect to the FTP server.

remarks.para: If this component is being used on a form or within another component then it is a good idea to use the "Connection Tester" to test the property settings.
Connections are not opened until the method is called. Connection-, Authentication-, and Security-related properties should be set prior to opening the connection.

At a minimum, the following properties should be set prior to connection.
Property Description
Protocol The protocol to use: SFTP, explicit FTPS, implicit FTPS or plain FTP.
ServerAddress The domain-name or IP-address of the server.
UserName User-name of account on the server.
Password Password of account on the server.

FTPS: If explicit FTPS has been selectedand is true (the default) then the component will try to secure the connection immediately after successfully connecting. A secure connection will always be attempted in implicit FTPS is selected regardless of the value of .

para.example: The following example illustrates the establishment of an explicit FTPS connection using automatic server validation

remarks.para: SFTP: SFTP connections always require some kind of authentication; this may be set using the property. Server validation is optional, but recommended; it is selected using the property.

para.example: The following example illustrates an SFTP client connecting to a server using simple password authentication but no server validation:
This example illustrates an SFTP client using public key authentication connecting to a server:

remarks.para: This method will throw an FTPException if the component is already connected to the server.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.SecureConnection
member.summary: [FTP/FTPS Only] Switches an explicit FTPS connection to secure mode.
member.remarks: It is not necessary to call this method if is set to true (the default) since this is then automatically done when the original connection is made. It is only necessary to do this if is set to false and the user wishes to manually control when the connection is switched to secure mode.
