member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.Protocol
member.summary: Type of secure FTP to use.
member.remarks:
Four types of file transfer are available:
Type
FTP Traditional unencrypted FTP.
FTPSExplicit FTP-over-SSL which allows switching between secure and unsecure transfers.
FTPSImplicit FTP-over-SSL which simply performs FTP over pure SSL sockets.
SFTP SSH File Transfer Protocol, which are secure file transfers via SSH.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.MaxTransferRate
member.summary: The maximum transfer rate in bytes per sec. Set to -1 or 0 for no bandwidth limiting.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.CompressionPreferred
member.summary: Flag to enable or disable compression for FTP/FTPS/SFTP transfers.

remarks.para: Some FTP/FTPS servers support the MODE Z command, permitting transfers to be compressed. This speeds up transfers significantly for files that are compressible such as text files. Most SFTP servers also support compression. Note that setting this flag to true does not guarantee that compression will occur, as it must be supported by the server.

If this flag is switched on, MODE Z compression is enabled if the FTP/FTPS server permits it. If the flag is later switched off, MODE Z compression is not disabled until the connection is closed and then re-opened again. For SFTP servers, zlib compression is set as the preferred compression, and will be used if supported by the server (and it can alter PreferredCompressionAlgorithms, adding zlib compression if it is not present).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.SocksProxySettings
member.summary: Settings for SOCKS proxy.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.ProxySettings
member.summary: Settings for using proxies.

remarks.para: Proxies may be used for FTPing through firewalls. HTTP and SOCKS (4,4A and 4) are supported.

SOCKS supports both passive (PASV) and active (PORT) mode transfers. Note that only passive mode transfers are possible via an HTTP proxy. There is no facility for HTTP proxies to listen for incoming connections, and hence active mode transfers cannot be done via an HTTP proxy. An exception will be thrown if they are attempted.
Often a username and password will be required to authenticate with the proxy. These can be set in ProxySettings.
ProxySettings is easiest to edit via the Property View.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.CommandEncoding
member.summary: The character-encoding to use when dealing with file- and directory-paths.
member.remarks:
The default is ASCII, except for SFTP but should be changed when communicating with FTP servers that have file-names containing non-ASCII characters
The default for SFTP is UTF-8, but may need to be changed for SFTP servers that do not support UTF-8 (typically SFTP version 3 or below).
Note that this value is NOT used for SFTP servers with a version number greater than 3 - UTF-8 is always used in these cases as per the standard.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.WelcomeMessage
member.summary: Server's welcome message.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.ServerCompatibility
member.summary: [SFTP/FTPS] Controls various server security compatibility features.

remarks.para:
Common server incompatibility problems are caused by differing levels of adherence to the relevant standards. This is particularly applicable to FTPS. For example, the standard dictates how SSL/TLS sockets should be closed. By default SecureFTPConnection will attempt to close sockets in the standard-compliant way. While this is the most secure, it occasionally will cause hanging as it waits for a response from the server which never arrives. The ServerCompatibility property is provided for controlling this behaviour. If you experience hanging when a data-transfer is complete using FTPS then you should first try
and, if the problem still occurs, . If you experience hanging as you close your FTPS session then you should first try and, if the problem still occurs, .

For SFTP, some servers return an error saying the file does not exist after creating it. By default, the client does a permission change after creating the file, which is done to ensure the file permissions are correct. If this error is encountered, try using to eliminate the problem.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.ServerValidation
member.summary: [SFTP/FTPS] Method by which the server's certificate or public key is validated.

remarks.para: The default for both SFTP and FTPS is .

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.ServerValidationCertificate
member.summary: [FTPS Only] Certificate used to validate the certificate presented by the server.
member.remarks: If the server certificate is signed by a valid Certificate Authority, this property need not be set, as it can be validated using the existing CA certificates controlled by Windows. If the certificate is self-signed (e.g. for testing) then it can't be validated unless it is imported into the trusted CA authorities certificate store. The alternative is to set this property, typically, to a copy of the server's certificate. If set, the certificate sent by the server is compared with this certificate. If they don't match, validation fails (even if the server's certificate is signed by a CA).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.AutoSecure
member.summary: [FTPS Only] Determines if the component will automatically switch to SSL/TLS upon connection when using FTPS.

remarks.para: If this flag if true and is or then the component will automatically switch to SSL/TLS upon connection. This is only relevant for explicit FTPS since implicit FTPS always operates over an SSL/TLS connection.
The default is true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.SecureFTPType
member.summary: This property has been deprecated. Please use .

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.SSLVersion
member.summary: [FTPS Only] Minimum SSL/TLS version to use.
member.remarks: edtFTPnet/PRO supports SSL 3.0, TLS 1.0, TLS 1.1 and TLS 1.2. TLS is the successor to SSL and should be used unless the server does not support it - SSL 3.0 has various vulnerabilities such as the POODLE exploit. SSLFTPSSLVersion.DETECT no longer will interoperate with SSL 3.0.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.MinSSLVersion
member.summary: [FTPS Only] Minimum SSL/TLS version to use.
member.remarks: edtFTPnet/PRO supports SSL 3.0, TLS 1.0, TLS 1.1 and TLS 1.2. TLS is the successor to SSL and should be used unless the server does not support it - SSL 3.0 has various vulnerabilities such as the POODLE exploit. SSLFTPSSLVersion.DETECT no longer will interoperate with SSL 3.0.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.MaxSSLVersion
member.summary: [FTPS Only] Maximum SSL/TLS version to use.
member.remarks: edtFTPnet/PRO supports SSL 3.0, TLS 1.0, TLS 1.1 and TLS 1.2. TLS is the successor to SSL and should be used unless the server does not support it - SSL 3.0 has various vulnerabilities such as the POODLE exploit. SSLFTPSSLVersion.DETECT no longer will interoperate with SSL 3.0.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.CipherSuites
member.summary: [FTPS Only] Get/sets the cipher-suites permissible during establishment of a secure connection.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.ServerCommonName
member.summary: [FTPS Only] The name to be used when performing a name-check during the validation of the server certificate.
member.remarks: An important part of validating the certificate is to perform a name-check. In a name-check the Common Name on the certificate is compared with the host-name of the FTP server that we believe we are connected to. Unless this property is set explicitly, the Common Name is assumed to be the same as the host-name that is used to connect to the server.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.UseSessionResumption
member.summary: [FTPS Only] Disables or enables SSL session resumption.

remarks.para: If this flag if true and is then the component will automatically use SSL session resumption when establishing new connections. Session resumption is primarily a performance enhancement - it avoids some of the stages of the SSL handshake, using previously cached session data.
The default is true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.SessionResumptionRequiresExtendedMasterSecret
member.summary: [FTPS Only] Controls/indicates whether this client requires using the extended master secret for TLS session resumption.

remarks.para: If this flag if true and is then the component will require the extended master secret to be used for TLS session resumption. This is to avoid a security hole in session resumption. However some servers don't support use of the extended master secret (and yet require session resumption). So the requirement can be disabled using this property.
The default is true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.UseClientHelloExtension
member.summary: [FTPS Only] Disables or enables SSL session resumption.

remarks.para: If this flag if true and is then the component will send the SSL client hello signature extension when TLS 1.2 is one of the protocol version options.

Some servers require that the TLS 1.2 signature extension is sent if TLS 1.2 is one of the version options listed in the client Hello, even though the TLS 1.2 RFC states that a server MUST accept ClientHello messages both with and without the extensions field.
So the default is to send the extension if, say, TLS 1.1 and TLS 1.2 are in the negotiation list. If this flag is false, the extension is only sent if TLS 1.2 is the minimum version possible.
The default is true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.UseUnencryptedCommands
member.summary: [FTPS Only] Switches the component to using an unencrypted command channel when using FTPS.

remarks.para: If this flag if true and is then the component will automatically switch to an unencrypted command channel after connection and login. If the component is already connected, setting this flag to true will switch to using an unencrypted command channel from this point onwards.
Not all FTPS servers support this feature (known as CCC, Clear Control Channel).
Once the command channel is changed to being unencrypted, it cannot be changed back to encrypted within the session.
This feature can sometimes be useful in getting past firewalls that need to be able to inspect command channels to open ports for directory listings and file transfers.
The default is false.
If things appear to hang here, set the ServerCompatibility property to SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.SSLDisableControlWaitOnShutdownSSL

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.UseUnencryptedData
member.summary: [FTPS Only] Switches the component to using an unencrypted data channel when using FTPS.

remarks.para: If this flag if true and is then the component will automatically switch to an unencrypted data channel after connection and login. If the component is already connected, setting this flag to true will switch to using an unencrypted data channel for transfers and listings from this point onwards.
The default is false.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.ClientCertificate
member.summary: [FTPS Only] The certificate to be presented to the server.
member.remarks: If a server requires client validation then this property must be set. s are created using one of the static SSLFTPCertificate.CreateFrom... methods to load a certificate from a file and the to load the associated private key.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.ServerCertificate

member.remarks: During the negotiation of a secure connection, the server presents a certificate which may be accessed using this property. The property may not be accessed until a secure connection has been made.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.IsControlChannelSecure

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.UMask
member.summary: [SFTP Only] The file creation mode mask that is applied to the default permissions to create the final permission set.

remarks.para: This property applies to SFTP only. Use the property to select the protocol.
The umask and the are specified in octal. The permission set of a new file is specified by taking the default permissions in octal, and subtracting the umask.
For example, if the are 777 and the umask is set to 022, the final create permissions will be 755 (777-022).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.DefaultPermissions
member.summary: [SFTP Only] The default file creation mode permissions (in octal).

remarks.para: This property applies to SFTP only. Use the property to select the protocol.

Permission strings consist of three fields - permissions for owner, group and other users. A typical executable file might have permissions of read,write and executable permissions set for the owner, and read and execute permissions for everyone else. This is typically displayed as rwxr-xr-x, in the order of owner|group|other.

Permission strings can also be presented in octal, which has certain advantages. An octal number corresponds to each type of permission: 4=read, 2=write and 1=execute. These are combined to form a group of permissions, i.e. a permissions field. For example, to specify that a file has read, write and execute permissions, it is assigned 4+2+1 = 7. So for the previous example of rwxr-wr-w, this can be represented in octal as 755, where the 5 comes from 4(read)+1(execute).
The default permissions are combined with the to form the final permission set for a new file.
For more details on permissions and umasks, see a Unix text or look up umask and chmod's man pages.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.AuthenticationMethod
member.summary: [SFTP/SCP Only] The current authentication method being used.

remarks.para: This property applies to SFTP only. Use the property to select the protocol.
Note that the different authentication types also have various required properties associated with them that are required to be set.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.ClientPrivateKeyFile

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.KBIPrompts
member.summary: [SFTP/SCP Only] Array of prompts used for keyboard interactive (KBI) authentication.

remarks.para: This property applies to SFTP/SCP only. Use the property to select the protocol.

Setting this property sets up keyboard interactive authentication. The prompts that the server will send to the client must be known. For each prompt, an must be created with the matching prompt string and the response to be sent back to the server. Often, a single password prompt is all that is required, and a is supplied for this purpose. For this property to be used, must be set to .

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.KnownHosts

member.value: Manager of the list of known hosts used to authenticate the server.

remarks.para: This property applies to SFTP only. Use the property to select the protocol.
This manager is used to set the known_hosts file containing a list of known hosts and their public keys. It is also used to add public keys explicitly.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.SSHMaxQueuedReadRequests
member.summary: [SFTP/SCP Only] SSH maximum size of read-request queue.

remarks.para: This property applies to SFTP/SCP only. In SFTP, files are read block-by-block. The client sends one request per block. Queueing up read-requests helps to counteract latencies. This property determines the number of read-requests that should be queued up. If it's set to 1 then no requests a queued up meaning that reads are done synchronously. The default is 32.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.SendInitialWindowAdjust
member.summary: [SFTP/SCP Only] Determines whether a SSH_MSG_CHANNEL_WINDOW_ADJUST message should be sent initially.

The default is generally appropriate in most situations.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.ParallelTransferMode
member.summary: [SFTP Only] Controls if parallel mode transfers are enabled.

remarks.para: Uploads are by default in parallel mode, which is faster than serial mode. This mode can be switched off if servers are unable to deal with parallel mode.
This property applies to SFTP only. Use the property to select the protocol.
The default is generally appropriate in most situations.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.CloseStreamsAfterTransfer
member.summary: Determines if transfer-methods taking s as arguments should close the stream once the transfer is completed.
member.remarks: If CloseStreamsAfterTransfer is true (the default) then streams are closed after a transfer has completed, otherwise they are left open.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPConnection.DeleteOnFailure
member.summary: Controls whether or not a file is deleted when a failure occurs.

remarks.para: If true, a partially downloaded file is deleted if there is a failure during the download. For example, the connection to the FTP server might have failed. If false, the partially downloaded file remains on the FTP client machine - and the download may be resumed, if it is a binary transfer.
By default this flag is set to true.

member.summary: Delegate used for ValidatingServer event

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPServerValidationType
member.summary: Specifies type of server valudation to use.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPServerValidationType.None
member.summary: Validates the server regardless of the certificate (FTPS) or public key (SFTP) that is presented.

summary.para: Automatically performs standard server validation to authenticate the server.

For SFTP, the list of known hosts that have been loaded by the client is searched for the server's IP address and hostname. The public key presented by the server is checked for a match against the public keys registered for that host. Note that if the server presents (for example) a DSA key, only a DSA key registered under the hostname or IP address for the server will be able to match. If a matching public key for the server is found, validation succeeds.

For FTPS, operating system resources are used to validate the certificate presented by the server. On Windows the installed certificates are used for this purpose. These certificates may be managed on the Contents tab of the Internet Options control panel.

Note that an important part of validating the certificate is to perform a name-check. In a name-check the Common Name on the certificate is compared with the host-name of the FTP server that we believe we are connected to. The Common Name to be used for name-checking is assumed to be the same as the host-name that was used upon connection, though it may be set manually using the .

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPServerValidationType.AutomaticNoNameCheck
member.summary: Same as but without name-checking. In the case of SFTP, all public keys loaded by the client are checked for a match irrespective of the hostname or IP address that they are registered under.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPServerValidationType.Callback
member.summary: A callback supplied by the user is used to validate the public key

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags
member.summary: Controls various server security compatibility features.

remarks.para:
Common server incompatibility problems are caused by differing level of adherence to the relevant standards. This is particularly applicable to FTPS. For example, the standard dictates how SSL/TLS sockets should be closed. By default SecureFTPConnection will attempt to close sockets in the standard-compliant way. While this is the most secure, it occasionally will cause hanging as it waits for a response from the client which never arrives. The ServerCompatibility property is provided for controlling this behaviour. If you experience hanging when a data-transfer is complete using FTPS then you should first try
and, if the problem still occurs, . If you experience hanging as you close your FTPS session then you should first try and, if the problem still occurs, .

For SFTP, some servers return an error saying the file does not exist after creating it. By default, the client does a permission change after creating the file, which is done to ensure the file permissions are correct. If this error is encountered, try using to eliminate the problem.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.Standard
member.summary: No special compatibility options, i.e. standard-compliant FTPS and SFTP.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.SSLDisableControlClosure
member.summary: FTPS only. Disables the SSL/TSL closure exchange on the control channel.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.SSLDisableDataClosure
member.summary: FTPS only. Disables the SSL/TSL closure exchange on data channels.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.SSLDisableControlWaitOnClose
member.summary: FTPS only. Prevents the client from waiting for a reply to the SSL/TLS closure command on the control channel.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.SSLDisableDataWaitOnClose
member.summary: FTPS only. Prevents the client from waiting for a reply to the SSL/TLS closure command on the data channel.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.SSLDisableControlWaitOnShutdownSSL
member.summary: FTPS only. Prevents the client from waiting for an ShutdownSSL message when calling UseUnencryptedCommands

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.SSHDisableChmodAfterPut
member.summary: SFTP only. Disables the permission change made after creating a file.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPCommandView
member.summary: FTPCommandView displays all FTP commands and their replies in real-time.

remarks.para: Commands are prefixed with the value of and replies are prefixed with .

A context-menu is displayed if the user right-clicks on the control. The context menu has options for clearing all messages; selecting all messages; clearing the current selection; copying messages to the clipboard; and freezing the display. Freezing the display means that no new messages are displayed.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView
member.summary: Base class for controls which need to display a list of messages.
member.remarks: FTPMessageView is a base-class for and . It displays a single list-box, with a right-click context menu that allows clearing, copying to clipboad, and freezing (i.e. ignoring new messages).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.Clear
member.summary: Clears all messages from the list.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.Copy
member.summary: Copies all messages (or the currently selected messages) to the clipboard.
member.remarks: If no messages are selected then all messages will be copied, otherwise only the selected messages will be copied.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.SetSelection(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Selects/unselects the message with the given index.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.SelectAll
member.summary: Selects all messages in the view.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.ClearSelection
member.summary: Clears the current selection.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.Freeze
member.summary: Prevents new messages from being displayed.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.Unfreeze
member.summary: Enables the display of new messages.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.PrintMessage(System.String)
member.summary: Adds the given message to the view.
member.remarks: The control ensures that no more than are displayed by deleting the oldest message(s).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.LinkComponent(EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.IFTPComponent)
member.summary: Called by the given FTP component when it is added to a container.
member.remarks: This method allows FTP components to interlink themselves automatically.
member.param: FTP component just added to the container.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.AllowContextMenu
member.summary: Determines whether or not to allow the context menu on right-click.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.Connection
member.summary: The or whose messages are to be displayed.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.ClearOnReconnect
member.summary: Controls whether or not messages are cleared when an FTP connection is opened.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.MaxMessages
member.summary: Maximum number of messages what will be displayed.
member.remarks: Once MaxMessages are displayed, the oldest message will be discarded each time a new message is added.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.AutoScroll
member.summary: Determines whether or not the control will keep the latest line visible.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.Messages
member.summary: All the messages currently being displayed.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.SelectedMessages
member.summary: All the messages that are currently selected.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.SelectedIndices
member.summary: The indices of the currently selected messages.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.SelectedIndex
member.summary: The index of the current selection, or -1 if no message is selected.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.SelectedMessage
member.summary: The currently selected message, or null if no message is selected.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.HorizontalScrollbar
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether a horizontal scroll bar is displayed in the control.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.ItemHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the height of an item in the view.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.SelectionMode
member.summary: Determines how list box items are selected.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.Text
member.summary: The currently selected message, or null if no message is selected.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.TopIndex
member.summary: Index of the first visible item in the list box control

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.Menu
member.summary: Get the context menu shown on right-click.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPMessageView.MenuItemUpload
member.summary: Get the menu-item representing clear.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPController
member.summary: Non-visual Windows Forms component attach user-defined buttons or menu-items to various operations of an or .

remarks.para: FTPController allows the developer to attach any with a Click-event to particular FTP operations. Such components are termed Click Event-Sources.

It is important to note that the FTPController is an optional component whose presence it not required for the other FTP controls to be able to operate and interact. Its only function is to link buttons, hyperlinks or menu-items to particular FTP actions; if desired, this may be done by explicitly calling methods on the FTP connection object.

FTPController supports the following Click event-sources:
Click Event-SourceFTP Operation
LoadEventSource Prompts the user for a file-name and tries to load the FTP connection properties from that file using the method.
SaveEventSource Prompts the user for a file-name and tries to save the properties of the associated or to that file using the method.
ConnectEventSource Causes the associated FTP connection to attempt to connect to an FTP server as defined by its properties (see ).
CloseEventSource Causes the associated FTP connection to close (see ).
RefreshEventSource Causes the associated FTP connection to get the content of the current directory (see ).
StopEventSource Causes the associated FTP connection to cancel the current transfer (see ).

Event-sources are enabled and disabled as appropriate. For example, initially only the Load, Save and Connect event-sources are enabled, and once the client has connected to the server only the Close and Refresh event-source will be enabled.
The dialog-boxes that are used to prompt the user for files may be manipulated using the and properties.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPFileList
member.summary: Displays a list of files and directories available for upload or download via FTP.

remarks.para: FTPFileList is an abstract class that provides much of the functionality required to display a list of files (and directories) that can be uploaded or downloaded via the various FTP protocols (including secure protocols such as SFTP and FTPS). It supports renaming of files, deleting of files, and transfer via drag and drop and double-click, as well as a right mouse button menu providing the same functionality.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPLocalFileList
member.summary: Displays a list of local files and directories available for upload via FTP.

remarks.para: FTPLocalFileList is analogous to a , and displays a list of local files and directories available for upload via FTP.
When an instance of FTPLocalFileList is placed on a Windows form, it will automatically detect an instance of or .

If the connection has been established to the FTP server, a listing of the current local working directory will be displayed. Clicking on a filename displayed in the list will cause the file to be uploaded to the current remote working directory of the connection

FTPLocalFileList also supports drag and drop in conjunction with . If files are dragged from an instance of FTPLocalFileList and dropped on an instance of FTPRemoteFileList, they will be downloaded to the current local directory, and the file list refreshed.

Renaming of local files is also supported by the standard single click mechanism, and local files can be deleted via the delete key. A warning prompt is displayed before the deletion occurs. Upload, rename and delete are also available as right mouse click menu items.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPLogView
member.summary: FTPLogView displays logging messages in real-time.

remarks.para: Logging messages provide detailed information about the internal operations of the FTP client components. The level of detail can be controlled by means of the property with being the lowest and being the highest.

A context-menu is displayed if the user right-clicks on the control. The context menu has options for clearing all messages; selecting all messages; clearing the current selection; copying messages to the clipboard; and freezing the display. Freezing the display means that no new messages are displayed.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPRemoteFileList
member.summary: Displays a list of remote files and directories available for download via FTP.

remarks.para: FTPRemoteFileList is analogous to a , and displays a list of remote files and directories available on an FTP server for download.
When an instance of FTPRemoteFileList is placed on a Windows form, it will automatically detect an instance of or .

If the connection has been established to the FTP server, a listing of the current remote working directory will be displayed. Clicking on a filename displayed in the list will cause the file to be downloaded to the current local working directory of the connection.

FTPRemoteFileList also supports drag and drop in conjunction with . If files are dragged from an instance of FTPRemoteFileList and dropped on an instance of FTPLocalFileList, they will be downloaded to the current local directory, and the file list refreshed.

Renaming of remote files is also supported by the standard single click mechanism, and remote files and directories can be deleted via the delete key. A warning prompt is displayed before the deletion occurs. Download, rename and delete are also available as right mouse click menu items.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPStatusBar
member.summary: FTPStatusBar is a status bar tailored for use with and , which provides realtime feedback about the current file transfer.

remarks.para: Typically, an FTPStatusBar is placed on the same Windows form as an instance of ExFTPConnection. It automatically detects an instance of . When the application is run and a transfer is initiated, the FTPStatusBar displays a number of realtime visual cues about the transfer.

It shows a progress bar giving a visual representation of the percentage of the file size transferred, the actual percentage, the amount of data transferred, the time taken for the transfer, the current transfer speed, and the name of the file. All of these properties are updated dynamically as the transfer proceeds. A cancel button is also provided on the status bar to cancel the transfer as it is happening.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPSynchronizeView
member.summary: Helps users synchronize a directory on an FTP server with one on the local machine.

remarks.para: FTPSynchronizeView presents the user with a comparison of the files in the current working directory on the server () with those in the working directory on the local machine ().

Files are matched by name with optional case-sensitivity (see ). The comparison is presented in the form a with one row for each matching pair of files and with columns showing the names, dates, size of these files, as well as a description of how their dates and sizes compare, and a what action would be required to synchronize them.

A check-box is displayed next to each file, which allows the user to determine whether or not the suggested action should be performed. A synchronize button is displayed in the top-right corner (by default). When it is pressed all of the checked actions will be performed.

FTPSynchronizeView is highly customizable. The following table shows different ways of controlling the file comparisons:
Behavior Properties
Transfer direction determines whether files are to be uploaded or downloaded.
Case sensitivity
File-name filtering , and
Date comparison
New/existing files and control whether only new files (i.e. ones not present on the target side) are displayed or whether only existing files (i.e. ones that exist on both sides) are displayed, respectively. By default both of these flags are off meaning that all files displayed.
File deletion controls whether or not files on the "target" side of the comparison will be deleted if they are not present on the "source" side. For example, if the transfer direction is set to upload and a file with a particular name is present on the server but there is no file with a matching name on the local machine then the suggested action will be to delete the file on the server.
Real-time updating If is true then FTPSynchronizeView will handle its FTP connection's directory-change events and automatically update its content in response. If it is false then the list will not be updated until is called.
Hide files with no recommended action.
Customized file comparisons may be defined by handling the event, which will allow the developer to specify the match-text and the action using their own comparison algorithm.
All text that appears in FTPSynchronizeView may be modified through the properties of and the sub-components exposed through , , , , and .

member.summary: Controls the direction of synchronization.
member.remarks: FTPSynchronizeView only works in one direction at a time, although the user can instantly switch directions by clicking the direction button. The Direction property may be used to control the direction programmatically.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPSynchronizeView.IgnoreCase
member.summary: Determines whether or not case is ignored when matching file-names.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPSynchronizeView.ExcludeFilesInFilter
member.summary: Controls whether the filter is an inclusion-filter or an exclusion-filter.
member.remarks: If ExcludeFilesInFilter is false (the default) then only the files that match the filter (if there is one) will be displayed. Otherwise only those that don't match it will be displayed.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPSynchronizeView.FilterType
member.summary: Controls whether the should be interpreted as a wildcard string or a regular expression.
member.remarks: Wildcard strings use a DOS-like notation where ? matches any single character and * matches multiple characters. Regular expressions are of the kind used in .

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPSynchronizeView.FileNameFilter
member.summary: File-name filter that controls which files are displayed.
member.remarks: FileNameFilter may contain multiple strings separated by commas. Each string may be a regular expression (as defined by ) or a wildcard string (where ? matches any single character and * matches multiple characters). The type of filter (wildcard or regular expression) may be chosen via the property. The filter may be used to exclude or include files; this behavior is selected via the property. By default files in the filter are included. If no filter is defined then all files will be considered.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPSynchronizeView.IgnoreDate
member.summary: Controls whether or not dates are taken into consideration when performing file comparisons.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPSynchronizeView.TransferNewOnly
member.summary: If TransferNewOnly is set then only files that do not exist on the target file-system will be considered.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPSynchronizeView.TransferMatchingOnly
member.summary: If TransferMatchingOnly is set then only files that exist both on the source and target file-systems will be considered.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPSynchronizeView.DeleteIfSourceAbsent
member.summary: When set, this flag will advise that if a file exists on the target but not on the source then that file should be deleted.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.DirDetails(System.String)
member.summary: List an HTML page's hrefs as an array of FTPFile objects.
member.remarks: Each href in the page is represented as an FTPFile object. hrefs that appear to be to other HTML pages are represented as directories (as they will contain their own list of hrefs). Non HTML references (e.g. links to files such as xyz.zip) are represented as files.
member.param: directory or HTML filename
member.returns: An array of objects.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.DirDetails(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the given directory's contents and optionally that of its subdirectories as an array of objects.

remarks.para: If includeSubdirectories is set to true then the property of objects corresponding to subdirectories will contain the content of that subdirectory.
This method works for Windows and most Unix FTP servers. Please inform EDT about unusual formats (support@enterprisedt.com).

member.param: Name of directory AND/OR filemask.
Use true if subdirectories are required.
member.returns: An array of objects.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.IsDirectory(System.String)
member.summary: Is this URL a directory of hrefs, i.e. a normal web page that can have its links displayed?

member.summary: Is this url an HTML page?

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.DirDetails
member.summary: List the current directory's hrefs as an array of FTPFile objects.
member.remarks: Each href in the page is represented as an FTPFile object. hrefs that appear to be to other HTML pages are represented as directories (as they will contain their own list of hrefs). Non HTML references (e.g. links to files such as xyz.zip) are represented as files.
member.returns: An array of objects.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.CancelTransfer
member.summary: Cancels the current transfer.
member.remarks: This method is generally called from a separate thread. Note that this may leave partially written files on the server or on local disk, and should not be used unless absolutely necessary. The server is not notified.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.Resume
member.summary: Make the next file transfer resume.

remarks.para: For downloads, if writing to a file, it is opened in append mode, and only the bytes required are transferred.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.ResumeDownload(System.Int64)
member.summary: Make the next download resume at a specific point.

remarks.para: This resume method allows the resume offset to be set explicitly for downloads. Offset bytes are skipped before downloading the file.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.CancelResume
member.summary: Cancel the resume. Use this method if something goes wrong and the client is left in an inconsistent state

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.DeleteOnFailure
member.summary: Controls whether or not a file is deleted when a failure occurs.

remarks.para: If true, a partially downloaded file is deleted if there is a failure during the download. For example, the connection to the HTTP server might have failed. If false, the partially downloaded file remains on the client machine - and the download may be resumed, if it is a binary transfer.
By default this flag is set to true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.ServerValidation
member.summary: Controls the way in which server certificates are validated.
member.remarks: When an SSL/TLS connection is being negotiated, the FTP server will present an SSL certificate to the client. s are used to control what the client does with this certificate. The default is . If ServerValidation is then must be handled.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.TransferBufferSize

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.TransferNotifyInterval
member.summary: The number of bytes transferred between each notification of the event.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.TransferNotifyListings
member.summary: By default the BytesTransferred event is not triggered during directory listings - this property can be used to enable this behaviour.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.TransferType
member.summary: The current file transfer type (BINARY or ASCII).
member.remarks: When the transfer-type is set to BINARY then files are transferred byte-for-byte such that the transferred file will be identical to the original. When the transfer-type is set to ASCII then end-of-line characters will be translated where necessary between Windows and UNIX formats.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Http.HttpClient.ProxySettings
member.summary: Settings for using proxies.

remarks.para: Proxies may be used for transferring files through firewalls. Only HTTP proxies are supported for HTTP transfers. supported.
Often a username and password will be required to authenticate with the proxy. These can be set in ProxySettings.
ProxySettings is easiest to edit via the Property View.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Script.ScriptEngine
member.summary:
Scripting engine, used to load FTP scripts and execute them. Generally, the only methods used should be the constructor and the ExecuteScript() methods.
The setter methods should be used with caution. Typically, when the script is run these setter methods are called to set various properties. This means any properties manually set with these methods will be overwritten.
member.author: Bruce Blackshaw

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.CancelTransfer
member.summary: Cancels the current transfer.
member.remarks: This method is generally called from a separate thread. Note that this may leave partially written files on the server or on local disk, and should not be used unless absolutely necessary. The server is not notified.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.Resume
member.summary: Make the next file transfer (put or get) resume.

remarks.para: For puts, the bytes already transferred are skipped over, while for gets, if writing to a file, it is opened in append mode, and only the bytes required are transferred.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.ResumeDownload(System.Int64)
member.summary: Make the next download resume at a specific point.

remarks.para: This resume method allows the resume offset to be set explicitly for downloads. Offset bytes are skipped before downloading the file.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.DeleteOnFailure
member.summary: Controls whether or not a file is deleted when a failure occurs.

remarks.para: If true, a partially downloaded file is deleted if there is a failure during the download. For example, the connection to the SFTP server might have failed. If false, the partially downloaded file remains on the SFTP client machine - and the download may be resumed, if it is a binary transfer.
By default this flag is set to true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.CloseStreamsAfterTransfer

member.remarks: This only applies to streams passed in to Get or Put methods - local files are always closed

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.ProxySettings
member.summary: Settings for using proxies.

remarks.para: Proxies may be used for FTPing through firewalls. HTTP and SOCKS (4,4A and 4) are supported.

SOCKS supports both passive (PASV) and active (PORT) mode transfers. Note that only passive mode transfers are possible via an HTTP proxy. There is no facility for HTTP proxies to listen for incoming connections, and hence active mode transfers cannot be done via an HTTP proxy. An exception will be thrown if they are attempted.
Often a username and password will be required to authenticate with the proxy. These can be set in ProxySettings.
ProxySettings is easiest to edit via the Property View.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.ServerCompatibility

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.AuthenticationMethod

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.KBIPrompts
member.summary: Array of prompts used for keyboard interactive (KBI) authentication.
member.remarks: Setting this property sets up keyboard interactive authentication. The prompts that the server will send to the client must be known. For each prompt, an must be created with the matching prompt string and the response to be sent back to the server. Often, a single password prompt is all that is required, and a is supplied for this purpose. For this property to be used, must be set to .

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.ChMod(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Changes the access permissions or modes of the specified file or directory.
member.param: the absolute mode of the file/directory. This must be the base 10 representation of the octal permissions
the path to the file/directory on the remote server

remarks.para: Modes determine who can read, change or execute a file.

blockquote.pre:
Absolute modes are octal numbers specifying the complete list of attributes for the files; you specify attributes by OR'ing together these bits.
0400 Individual read 0200 Individual write 0100 Individual execute (or list directory) 0040 Group read 0020 Group write 0010 Group execute 0004 Other read 0002 Other write

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.Resume
member.summary: Make the next file transfer (put or get) resume.

remarks.para: For puts, the bytes already transferred are skipped over, while for gets, if writing to a file, it is opened in append mode, and only the bytes required are transferred.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.ResumeDownload(System.Int64)
member.summary: Make the next download resume at a specific point.

remarks.para: This resume method allows the resume offset to be set explicitly for downloads. Offset bytes are skipped before downloading the file.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.FilenameEncoding
member.summary: The character-encoding to use for file and directory names.

remarks.para: The default is UTF-8, but may need to be changed for SFTP servers that do not support UTF-8 (typically SFTP version 3 or below).
Note that this value is NOT used for SFTP servers with a version number greater than 3 - UTF-8 is always used in these cases as per the standard.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.TransferType
member.summary: The current file transfer type (BINARY or ASCII).
member.value: Transfer-type to be used for uploads and downloads.
member.remarks: When the transfer-type is set to BINARY then files are transferred byte-for-byte such that the transferred file will be identical to the original. When the transfer-type is set to ASCII then end-of-line characters will be translated where necessary between Windows and UNIX formats.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.ParallelTransferMode
member.summary: Uploads are by default in parallel mode, which is faster than serial mode. This mode can be switched off if servers are unable to deal with parallel mode.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.UMask
member.summary: Set and get the umask, the file creation mode mask that is applied to the default permissions to create the final permission set.

remarks.para: The umask and the are specified in octal. The permission set of a new file is specified by taking the default permissions in octal, and subtracting the umask.
For example, if the are 777 and the umask is set to 022, the final create permissions will be 755 (777-022).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.DefaultPermissions
member.summary: Set and get the default file creation mode permissions (in octal).

remarks.para: Permission strings consist of three fields - permissions for owner, group and other users. A typical executable file might have permissions of read,write and executable permissions set for the owner, and read and execute permissions for everyone else. This is typically displayed as rwxr-xr-x, in the order of owner|group|other.

Permission strings can also be presented in octal, which has certain advantages. An octal number corresponds to each type of permission: 4=read, 2=write and 1=execute. These are combined to form a group of permissions, i.e. a permissions field. For example, to specify that a file has read, write and execute permissions, it is assigned 4+2+1 = 7. So for the previous example of rwxr-wr-w, this can be represented in octal as 755, where the 5 comes from 4(read)+1(execute).
The default permissions are combined with the to form the final permission set for a new file.
For more details on permissions and umasks, see a Unix text or look up umask and chmod's man pages.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.KBIPrompts
member.summary: Array of prompts used for keyboard interactive (KBI) authentication.
member.remarks: Setting this property sets up keyboard interactive authentication. The prompts that the server will send to the client must be known. For each prompt, an must be created with the matching prompt string and the response to be sent back to the server. Often, a single password prompt is all that is required, and a is supplied for this purpose. For this property to be used, must be set to .

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPCertificate
member.summary: Contains information regarding an X.509v3 certificate.

remarks.para: Certificates are used here in two basic ways: (1) to validate the server to the client, and (2) to validate the client to the server. In the former case, the certificate is obtained from the server. In the latter case, the certificate must be loaded from a file.

Certificates may be loaded from files using one of the following three methods:
CreateFromCER(...) Loads the certificate from a CER file
CreateFromPEM(...) Loads the certificate from a PEM file
CreateFromPFX(...) Loads the certificate from a PFX file
Private keys may be loaded from a PVK file and associated with a certificate using the AssociatePrivateKey(string,string) method.
Instances of this class should be managed via using or Dispose.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPCertificate.PromptForCertificate(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Prompts the user for a certificate file and a matching private key.
member.remarks: This method will first prompt for a certificate file of format CER, PEM or PFX. If the file is a PFX file it will then prompt for a password to access this file. If promptForPrivateKey is true then the user will be prompted for a private key file of the PVK format and a matching password.
member.param: Should the user also be prompted for a private key
member.returns: An instance of SSLFTPCertificate with the associated private key.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPCipherSuite
member.summary: Enumeration of cipher-suites available.
member.remarks:
The value SECURE_CIPHERS combines all ciphers currently regarded as secure, which is currently all 128+ bit RSA-based ciphers. Other combinations may be created by ORing values together as follows:
SSLFTPCipherSuite.DHE_RSA_DES_SHA | SSLFTPCipherSuite.RSA_3DES_168_SHA

member.author: Hans Andersen

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.PROT_CLEAR
member.summary: May be passed to the prot(char) method to specify that data-transfers should be done WITHOUT security.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.PROT_PRIVATE
member.summary: May be passed to the prot(char) method to specify that data-transfers should be done WITH security.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.Connect
member.summary: Connects to the FTP server.

remarks.para: The property must be set before this method is called.
Note that for explicit FTP communications will not be secure until the Auth() method is called.
Implicit FTPS communications are secure from the outset, usually requiring no extra action by the client. Some servers, however may require Auth() (no arguments) to be called.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.Quit
member.summary: Quit the FTP session by sending a QUIT command before closing the socket.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.Auth
member.summary: (Implicit FTPS only) Instructs the server that data-channels should be secure.
member.remarks: Although most implicit FTPS servers secure data-channels by default, thus removing the need for this method, some do not. These server require that this method be called to ensure that data-channels are secure.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.Auth(EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPSSLVersion)
member.summary: Switches the control-channel (the connection which carries commands) to secure mode.
member.remarks: If this command succeeds, then all subsequent commands and their corresponding replies will be secure. The client will also switch to private (i.e. secure) data channels immediately after a connection is made. It does this by invoking Pbsz(0) and Prot(DataProtectionType.Private).
member.param: Version of SSL to use

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.Auth(EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPSSLVersion,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Switches the control-channel (the connection which carries commands) to secure mode.
member.remarks: If this command succeeds, then all subsequent commands and their corresponding replies will be secure. If secureDataChannels is true thenthe client will also switch to private (i.e. secure) data channels immediately after a connection is made. It does this by invoking Pbsz(0) and Prot(SSLFTPClient.DataProtectionType.Private).
member.param: Minimum version of SSL to use
Flag instructing whether or not to secure the data-channels.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.Auth(EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPSSLVersion,EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPSSLVersion,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Switches the control-channel (the connection which carries commands) to secure mode.
member.remarks: If this command succeeds, then all subsequent commands and their corresponding replies will be secure. If secureDataChannels is true thenthe client will also switch to private (i.e. secure) data channels immediately after a connection is made. It does this by invoking Pbsz(0) and Prot(SSLFTPClient.DataProtectionType.Private).
member.param: Minimum version of SSL to use
Maximum version of SSL to use
Flag instructing whether or not to secure the data-channels.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.ClearControlChannel
member.summary: Clears the control channel, setting it back to plain text.

remarks.para: After this command is issued, the server will continue the control connection in plaintext, expecting the next command from the client to be in plaintext. This command is often used in conjunction with firewalls, which need to be able to inspect the control channel to open data channel ports in the firewall. This can only be done if the control channel is not encrypted.
The server will not accept any more PBSZ or PROT commands. All subsequent data transfers must be protected with the current PROT settings.
If things appear to hang here, set the ServerCompatibility property to SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.SSLDisableControlWaitOnShutdownSSL

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.Prot(EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPDataProtectionType)
member.summary: Defines the security-level of subsequent data-transfers.
member.remarks: One of the Auth() methods must be called prior to calling this method. In most cases, calling Auth() will also implicitly cause this method to be called, so it's usually unnecessary to call this method explicitly.
member.param: Protection type - either or .

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.Pbsz(System.Int32)
member.summary: Defines the buffer-size to be used on data-connections.

remarks.para: In conformity with the standard, this method must be 0 (zero). Note that this method is required only to conform with the standard.

One of the Auth() methods must be called prior to calling this method. In most cases, calling Auth() will also implicitly cause this method to be called, so it's usually unnecessary to call this method explicitly.

member.param: Buffer-size to use (must be zero).

member.summary: Called when a server needs to be verified.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.ServerCompatibility
member.summary: Controls various server security compatibility features.

remarks.para: The most severe barrier to server compatilibilty is the lack of FTPS support on the server. Most FTP servers can be configured to support FTPS, but some only support SFTP (SSH File Transfer Protocol), which in fact is not FTP in the conventional sense. SFTP is not supported by SSLFTPClient.

The second most common server incompatibility problem is caused by differing level of adherence to the standard for how SSL/TLS sockets should be closed. By default SSLFTPClient will attempt to close sockets in the standard-compliant way. While this is the most secure, it occasionally will cause hanging as it waits for a response from the client which never arrives. The property is provided for controlling this behaviour. If you experience hanging when a data-transfer is complete then you should first try SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.DisableDataSSLWaitOnClose and, if the problem still occurs, SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.SSLDisableDataClosure. If you experience hanging as you close your secure FTP session then you should first try SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.SSLDisableControlWaitOnClose and, if the problem still occurs, SecureFTPCompatibilityFlags.SSLDisableControlClosure.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.ClientCertificate
member.summary: The certificate to be presented to the server.
member.remarks: If a server requires client validation then this property must be set. s are created using one of the static SSLFTPCertificate.CreateFrom... methods, which read a private key and a certificate from files.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.ServerCertificate
member.summary: The certificate presented by the server.
member.remarks: During the negotiation of a secure connection, the server presents a certificate which may be accessed using this property. The property may not be accessed until a secure connection has been made.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.IsControlChannelSecure
member.summary: Indicates whether the control channel is currently secure.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.IsImplicitFTPS
member.summary: Controls/indicates whether this client is performing explicit or implicit FTPS.
member.value: true if the client is performing implicit FTPS. false is the default.

remarks.para: Implicit FTPS is an older form of FTPS which uses pure SSL connection, i.e. SSL sessions are established immediately upon socket connection for all FTP channels.
This property may be read any time, but may be set only prior to connection.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.UseSessionResumption
member.summary: Controls/indicates whether this client is using SSL session resumption
member.value: true if the client using session resumption true is the default.

remarks.para: Session resumption is primarily a performance enhancement - it avoids some of the stages of the SSL handshake, using previously cached session data.
This property may be read any time, but may be set only prior to connection.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.SessionResumptionRequiresExtendedMasterSecret
member.summary: Controls/indicates whether this client requires using the extended master secret for TLS session resumption.
member.value: true if the client requires the extended master secret for TLS session resumption true is the default.

remarks.para: Session resumption is primarily a performance enhancement - it avoids some of the stages of the SSL handshake, using previously cached session data. For security, the specification requires the extended master secret to be used for session resumption, but some servers don't support it (and yet require session resumption). So it can be disabled using this property.
This property may be read any time, but may be set only prior to connection.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.UseClientHelloExtension
member.summary: Controls/indicates whether this client is using the SSL client hello signature extension for when TLS 1.2 is one of the protocol version options
member.value: true if the client is using the SSL client hello signature extension for when TLS 1.2 is one of the protocol version options. true is the default.

remarks.para: Some servers require that the TLS 1.2 signature extension is sent if TLS 1.2 is one of the version options listed in the client Hello, even though the TLS 1.2 RFC states that "A server MUST accept ClientHello messages both with and without the extensions field".
So the default is to send the extension if, say, TLS 1.1 and TLS 1.2 are in the negotiation list. If this flag is false, the extension is only sent if TLS 1.2 is the minimum version possible.
This property may be read any time, but may be set only prior to connection.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.ServerValidation
member.summary: Controls the way in which server certificates are validated.
member.remarks: When an SSL/TLS connection is being negotiated, the FTP server will present an SSL certificate to the client. s are used to control what the client does with this certificate. The default is . If ServerValidation is then must be handled.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.CipherSuites
member.summary: Get/sets the cipher-suites permissible during establishment of a secure connection.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.SSLVersion
member.summary: Get/sets the minimum SSL/TLS version to use. TLS is the successor to SSL and should be used unless the server does not support it - SSL 3.0 has various vulnerabilities such as the POODLE exploit. SSLFTPSSLVersion.DETECT no longer will interoperate with SSL 3.0.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.MinSSLVersion
member.summary: Get/sets the minimum SSL/TLS version to use. TLS is the successor to SSL and should be used unless the server does not support it - SSL 3.0 has various vulnerabilities such as the POODLE exploit. SSLFTPSSLVersion.DETECT no longer will interoperate with SSL 3.0.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.MaxSSLVersion
member.summary: Get/sets the maximum SSL/TLS version to use. TLS is the successor to SSL and should be used unless the server does not support it - SSL 3.0 has various vulnerabilities such as the POODLE exploit. SSLFTPSSLVersion.DETECT no longer will interoperate with SSL 3.0.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.ServerCommonName
member.summary: The name to be used when performing a name-check during the validation of the server certificate.
member.remarks: An important part of validating the certificate is to perform a name-check. In a name-check the Common Name on the certificate is compared with the host-name of the FTP server that we believe we are connected to. Unless this property is set explicitly, the Common Name is assumed to be the same as the host-name that is used to connect to the server.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssl.SSLFTPClient.RootCertificates
member.summary: Returns an array containing all root certificates.

remarks.para: If is set to or then the system will attempt to validate the server's certificate. For a certificate to be validated it must either (1) be installed as a root certificate, or (2) the base of the chain of certificates that it contains must be a root certificate.

Root Certificates work through "Chains of Trust". In other words, if X trusts Y, and Y trusts Z, then X can trust Z. In this case, X is the user of the FTP-client, Y is a Certification Authority (CA), and Z is the FTP server. So, in order for the FTP-client to be able to trust the FTP-server, the server should have a certificate issued by a CA, and the client should have the CA's certificate loaded as a root certificate. When a client connects to a server, the server will provide the client with its certificate. This certificate will contain a copy of the CA's certificate and contain data which certifies that the server's certificate could only have been issued by this CA. The client can now match the CA's certificate with the root certificates that it holds and then deduce whether or not the server is trustworthy. Client certificates work similarly, but in reverse to the above description.
Installing certificates: A certificate may be installed on the system using the Internet Properties settings, which may be accessed from the Windows Control Panel.

member.summary: The certificate is valid.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.Expired
member.summary: A required certificate is not within its validity period.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidBasicConstraints
member.summary: The certificate's basic constraints are invalid or missing.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidChain
member.summary: A chain of certificates was not correctly created.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidNesting
member.summary: The validity periods of the certification chain do not nest correctly.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidPurpose
member.summary: A certificate is being used for a non permitted purpose.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidRole
member.summary: A certificate that can only be used as an end-entity is being used as a CA or visa versa.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidSignature
member.summary: The signature of the certificate cannot be verified.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.NoCNMatch
member.summary: The certificate's CN name does not match the passed value.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.ParentRevoked
member.summary: A certificate in the chain has been explicitly revoked by its issuer.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.RevocationFailure
member.summary: The revocation process could not continue. The certificates could not be checked.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.RevocationServerOffline
member.summary: Since the revocation server was offline, the called function was not able to complete the revocation check.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.Revoked
member.summary: The certificate or signature has been revoked.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.UntrustedRoot
member.summary: A certification chain processed correctly but terminated in a root certificate not trusted by the trust provider.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.UntrustedTestRoot
member.summary: The root certificate is a testing certificate and policy settings disallow test certificates.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.WrongUsage
member.summary: The certificate is not valid for the requested usage.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidName
member.summary: The certificate has an invalid name. Either the name is not included in the permitted list, or it is explicitly excluded.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidPolicy
member.summary: The certificate has an invalid policy.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.Critical
member.summary: The certificate is being used for a purpose other than the purpose specified by its CA.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.NoRevocationCheck
member.summary: The revocation function was unable to check revocation for the certificate

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.OtherError
member.summary: The certificate is invalid.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions
member.summary: Defines additional options for building a certificate chain.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.Default
member.summary: The default chain options

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.RevocationCheckEndCert
member.summary: Revocation checking is done on the end certificate and only the end certificate.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.RevocationCheckChain
member.summary: Revocation checking is done on all of the certificates in every chain.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.RevocationCheckChainExcludeRoot
member.summary: Revocation checking in done on all certificates in all of the chains except the root certificate.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.RevocationCacheEndCert
member.summary: When this flag is set, the end certificate is cached, which might speed up the chain-building process. By default, the end certificate is not cached and it would need to be verified each time a chain is built for it.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.RevocationCheckCacheOnly
member.summary: Revocation checking only accesses cached URLs and does not hit the wire to do any revocation URL retrieval. Supported on Windows Me, Windows 2000 and later.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.CacheOnlyUrlRetrieval
member.summary: Uses only cached URLs in building a certificate chain. The Internet and Intranet are not searched for URL-based objects. Note, not applicable to revocation checking. Set CERT_CHAIN_REVOCATION_CHECK_CACHE_ONLY to use only cached URLs for revocation checking.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.DisablePass1QualityFiltering
member.summary: For performance reasons, the second pass of chain building only considers potential chain paths that have quality greater than or equal to the highest quality determined during the first pass. The first pass only considers valid signature, complete chain and trusted roots to calculate chain quality. This flag can be set to disable this optimization and consider all potential chain paths during the second pass.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.ReturnLowerQualityContexts
member.summary: The default is to return only the highest quality chain path. Setting this flag will return the lower quality chains. These are returned in the chain context's cLowerQualityChainContext and rgpLowerQualityChainContext fields.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.DisableAuthRootAutoUpdate
member.summary: Setting this flag inhibits the auto update of third party roots from the Windows Update Web Server.

member.summary: Gets or sets the block size of the cryptographic operation in bits.
member.value: The block size of RC4 is always 8 bits.
member.exception: The block size is invalid.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.FeedbackSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the feedback size of the cryptographic operation in bits.
member.value: This property always throws a .
member.exception: This exception is always thrown.
member.remarks: RC4 doesn't use the FeedbackSize property.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.IV
member.summary: Gets or sets the initialization vector (IV) for the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: This property always returns a byte array of length one. The value of the byte in the array is always set to zero.
member.exception: An attempt is made to set the IV to an invalid instance.
member.remarks: RC4 doesn't use the IV property, however the property accepts IV's of up to one byte (RC4's ) in order to interoperate with software that has been written with the use of block ciphers in mind.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.LegalBlockSizes
member.summary: Gets the block sizes that are supported by the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: An array containing the block sizes supported by the algorithm.
member.remarks: Only a block size of one byte is supported by the RC4 algorithm.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.LegalKeySizes
member.summary: Gets the key sizes that are supported by the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: An array containing the key sizes supported by the algorithm.
member.remarks: Only key sizes that match an entry in this array are supported by the symmetric algorithm.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.Mode
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode for operation of the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The mode for operation of the symmetric algorithm.
member.remarks: RC4 only supports the OFB cipher mode. See for a description of this mode.
member.exception: The cipher mode is not OFB.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.Padding
member.summary: Gets or sets the padding mode used in the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The padding mode used in the symmetric algorithm. This property always returns PaddingMode.None.
member.exception: The padding mode is set to a padding mode other than PaddingMode.None.

member.summary: Specifies the type of encryption method to use when protecting data.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.ProtectionType.LocalMachine
member.summary: The encrypted data is associated with the local machine. Any user on the computer on which the data is encrypted can decrypt the data.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.ProtectionType.CurrentUser
member.summary: The encrypted data is associated with the current user. Only a user with logon credentials matching those of the encrypter can decrypt the data.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.PUBLICKEYSTRUC.bType
member.summary: Key BLOB type. The only BLOB types currently defined are PUBLICKEYBLOB, PRIVATEKEYBLOB, SIMPLEBLOB, and PLAINTEXTBLOB. Other key BLOB types will be defined as needed.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.PUBLICKEYSTRUC.bVersion

member.summary: WORD reserved for future use. Must be set to zero.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.PUBLICKEYSTRUC.aiKeyAlg
member.summary: Algorithm identifier for the key contained by the key BLOB. Some examples are CALG_RSA_SIGN, CALG_RSA_KEYX, CALG_RC2, and CALG_RC4.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.DataProtectionCryptoServiceProvider
member.summary:
The DataProtectionCryptoServiceProvider is a class that performs encryption and decryption on data without explicitly requiring a password.
There are two different types of encryption. The first type will associate the encrypted data with the logon credentials of the current user. Hence only a user with matching logon credentials can decrypt the data.
The second type will associate the encrypted data with the local machine. Any user of a specific machine will be able to decrypt encrypted data under this scheme.
This class cannot be inherited.

member.param: A buffer holding any additional entropy that can be used during encryption and decryption.
member.remarks: The same entropy must be provided during the encryption and decryption process. Otherwise, the decryption will fail.
