member.summary: Encrypts data according to a specified protection type.
member.param: One of the values.
The data to encrypt.
member.exception: data is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).

An error occurs during the encryption process. Under some circumstances, Microsoft cryptographic service providers may not allow encryption when used in France. This may occur on down-level platforms such as Windows 98 and Windows NT 4.0, depending on the system's configuration and the version of the CSPs.
member.returns: An array of encrypted bytes.
member.remarks: The number of the returned bytes will be larger than the number of input bytes. The method will use the entropy from the property.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.DHKeyGeneration
member.summary: Defines the different Diffie-Hellman key generation methods.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.DHKeyGeneration.Random
member.summary: Returns dynamically generated values for P and G. Unlike the Sophie Germain or DSA key generation methods, this method does not ensure that the selected prime offers an adequate security level.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.DHKeyGeneration.Static
member.summary: Returns values for P and G that are hard coded in this library. Contrary to what your intuition may tell you, using these hard coded values is perfectly safe. The values of the P and G parameters are taken from 'The OAKLEY Key Determination Protocol' [RFC2412]. This is the prefered key generation method, because it is very fast and very safe. Because this method uses fixed values for the P and G parameters, not all bit sizes are supported. The current implementation supports bit sizes of 768, 1024 and 1536.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4CryptoServiceProvider.IV
member.summary: Gets or sets the initialization vector (IV) for the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: This property always returns a byte array of length one. The value of the byte in the array is always set to zero.
member.exception: An attempt is made to set the IV to an invalid instance.
member.remarks: RC4 doesn't use the IV property, however the property accepts IV's of up to one byte (RC4's ) in order to interoperate with software that has been written with the use of block ciphers in mind.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.BlockSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the block size of the cryptographic operation in bits.
member.value: The block size in bits.
member.exception: The block size is invalid.
member.remarks: The block size is the basic unit of data that can be encrypted or decrypted in one operation. Messages longer than the block size are handled as successive blocks; messages shorter than the block size must be padded with extra bits to reach the size of a block. Valid block sizes are determined by the symmetric algorithm used.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.FeedbackSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the feedback size of the cryptographic operation in bits.
member.value: The feedback size in bits.
member.exception: The feedback size is larger than the block size.
member.remarks: The feedback size determines the amount of data that is fed back to successive encryption or decryption operations. The feedback size cannot be greater than the block size.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.IV
member.summary: Gets or sets the initialization vector (IV) for the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The initialization vector.
member.exception: An attempt is made to set the IV to a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An attempt is made to set the IV to an invalid size.
member.remarks: If this property is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) when it is used, is called to create a new random value.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.Key
member.summary: Gets or sets the secret key for the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The secret key to be used for the symmetric algorithm.
member.exception: An attempt is made to set the key to a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).

remarks.para: The secret key is used both for encryption and for decryption. For a symmetric algorithm to be secure, the secret key must be known only to the sender and the receiver. The valid key sizes are specified by the particular symmetric algorithm implementation and are listed in .
If this property is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) when it is used, is called to create a new random value.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.KeySize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the secret key used by the symmetric algorithm in bits.

member.exception: The key size is not valid.
member.remarks: The valid key sizes are specified by the particular symmetric algorithm implementation and are listed in .

member.summary: Gets the block sizes that are supported by the symmetric algorithm.

member.remarks: Only block sizes that match an entry in this array are supported by the symmetric algorithm.

member.summary: Gets the key sizes that are supported by the symmetric algorithm.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.Mode
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode for operation of the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The mode for operation of the symmetric algorithm.
member.exception: The cipher mode is not one of the CipherMode values.
member.remarks: See CipherMode for a description of specific modes.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.Padding
member.summary: Gets or sets the padding mode used in the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The padding mode used in the symmetric algorithm.
member.exception: The padding mode is not one of the PaddingMode values.
member.remarks: Most plain text messages do not consist of a number of bytes that completely fill blocks. Often, there are not enough bytes to fill the last block. When this happens, a padding string is added to the text. For example, if the block length is 64 bits and the last block contains only 40 bits, 24 bits of padding are added. See for a description of specific modes.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecureSocket
member.summary: Implements the Berkeley sockets interface and optionally encrypts/decrypts transmitted data.
member.remarks: Any public static (Shared in Visual Basic) members of this type are safe for multithreaded operations. Any instance members are not guaranteed to be thread safe.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket
member.summary: Implements the Berkeley sockets interface.
member.remarks: The VirtualSocket class implements exactly the same methods as the System.Net.Sockets.Socket class, however all these methods are marked as virtual so they can be overridden in derived classes. In addition to the constructor specified by the Socket class, the VirtualSocket class also has a constructor that accepts an already created Socket; this can be very useful is you have to override the Accept and BeginAccept/EndAccept methods in a derived class.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.#ctor(System.Net.Sockets.AddressFamily,System.Net.Sockets.SocketType,System.Net.Sockets.ProtocolType)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the VirtualSocket class.
member.param: One of the values.
One of the values.
One of the values.
member.exception: The combination of , , and results in an invalid socket.
member.remarks:
The parameter specifies the addressing scheme that the VirtualSocket uses, the parameter specifies the type of the VirtualSocket, and specifies the protocol used by the VirtualSocket. The three parameters are not independent. Some address families restrict which protocols can be used with them, and often the socket type is implicit in the protocol. If the combination of address family, socket type, and protocol type results in an invalid VirtualSocket, a SocketException is thrown.
The AddressFamily enumeration defines the valid address families, the SocketType enumeration defines the valid socket types, and the ProtocolType enumeration defines the valid protocol types.

member.remarks: VirtualSocket options determine the behavior of the current instance. Upon successful completion, GetSocketOption returns an object describing the requested option. For example, if you specify Linger as the option, a LingerOption is returned.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Receive(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Receives data from a connected VirtualSocket in a specific location of the receive buffer.
member.param: The storage location for received data.
member.returns: The number of bytes received.
member.exception: is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An operating system error occurs while accessing the VirtualSocket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.para: This overload only requires you to provide a receive buffer. The offset defaults to 0, size defaults to the buffer length, and the socketFlags value defaults to None.

The Blocking determines the behavior of this method when no incoming data is available. When false, a SocketException is thrown. When true, this method blocks and waits for data to arrive. For Stream Socket types, if the remote Socket was shut down gracefully, and all the data was received, this method immediately returns zero, regardless of the blocking state.

If you are using a message-oriented Socket, and the message is larger than the size of the buffer parameter, buffer is filled with the first part of the message, and a SocketException is thrown. With unreliable protocols the excess data is lost; with reliable protocols, the data is retained by the service provider.

Note If you specify the OutOfBand flag as the socketFlags parameter, and the Socket is configured for in-line reception of out-of-band (OOB) data (using the OutOfBandInline option) and OOB data is available, then only OOB data is returned. When the Peek flag is specified as the socketFlags parameter, available data is copied into the receive buffer but is not removed from the system buffer.

member.summary: Receives data from a connected VirtualSocket in a specific location of the receive buffer.
member.param: The storage location for received data.
The location in buffer to store the received data.
The number of bytes to receive.
A bitwise combination of the SocketFlags values.
member.returns: The number of bytes received.
member.exception: is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
The specified offset or size exceeds the size of buffer.
An operating system error occurs while accessing the VirtualSocket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.para: The Blocking determines the behavior of this method when no incoming data is available. When false, a SocketException is thrown. When true, this method blocks and waits for data to arrive. For Stream Socket types, if the remote Socket was shut down gracefully, and all the data was received, this method immediately returns zero, regardless of the blocking state.

If you are using a message-oriented Socket, and the message is larger than the size of the buffer parameter, buffer is filled with the first part of the message, and a SocketException is thrown. With unreliable protocols the excess data is lost; with reliable protocols, the data is retained by the service provider.

Note If you specify the OutOfBand flag as the socketFlags parameter, and the Socket is configured for in-line reception of out-of-band (OOB) data (using the OutOfBandInline option) and OOB data is available, then only OOB data is returned. When the Peek flag is specified as the socketFlags parameter, available data is copied into the receive buffer but is not removed from the system buffer.

When the SocketFlags. Peek flag is specified as the socketFlags parameter, available data is copied into the receive buffer but not removed from the system buffer.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Send(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Sends data to a connected VirtualSocket, starting at the indicated location in the data.
member.param: The data to be sent.
member.returns: The number of bytes sent to the VirtualSocket.
member.exception: is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An operating system error occurs while accessing the socket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.para: Use Send for connection-oriented protocols only. For connectionless protocols, either use SendTo or call Connect first, and then call Send. This overload only requires you to provide a data buffer. The offset defaults to 0, the size defaults to the buffer length, and SocketFlags value defaults to None.
You must set the LocalEndPoint property of the current instance before calling this method.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Send(System.Byte[],System.Net.Sockets.SocketFlags)
member.summary: Sends data to a connected VirtualSocket, starting at the indicated location in the data.
member.param: The data to be sent.
A bitwise combination of the SocketFlags values.
member.returns: The number of bytes sent to the VirtualSocket.
member.exception: is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An operating system error occurs while accessing the socket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.para: Use Send for connection-oriented protocols only. For connectionless protocols, either use SendTo or call Connect first, and then call Send.
This overload only requires you to provide a data buffer and SocketFlags. The offset defaults to 0, and the size parameter defaults to the buffer length.
You must set the LocalEndPoint property of the current instance before calling this method.

If you specify the DontRoute flag as the socketflags parameter, the data you are sending will not be routed. If you specify the OutOfBand flag as the socketflags parameter, only out-of-band (OOB) data is sent.
If you set the Blocking property to true, and buffer space is not available within the underlying protocol, this method blocks.
If you are using a message-oriented Socket, and the size of the buffer is greater than the maximum message size of the underlying protocol, no data is sent and Socket will throw a SocketException.

is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).

The remoteEP parameter is a null reference (Nothing).

remarks.para: If you are using a connection-oriented protocol or a connected Socket using a connectionless protocol, remoteEP overrides the endpoint specified in RemoteEndPoint. If you are using an unconnected Socket with a connectionless protocol, this method sets the LocalEndPoint property of the current instance to a value determined by the protocol. You must subsequently receive data on the LocalEndPoint. This overload only requires you to provide a data buffer, and the remote EndPoint. The offset defaults to 0. The size defaults to the buffer length, and SocketFlags value defaults to None.

member.remarks:
Socket options determine the behavior of the current Socket. Use this overload to set those Socket options that require a byte array as an option value.
Windows 98, Windows NT 4.0 Platform Note: You must call the Bind method before using AddMembership as the optionName parameter.

Socket options determine the behavior of the current Socket. For an option with a Boolean data type, specify a nonzero value to enable the option, and a zero value to disable the option. For an option with an integer data type, specify the appropriate value. Socket options are grouped by level of protocol support.
Windows 98, Windows NT 4.0 Platform Note: You must call the Bind method before using AddMembership as the optionName parameter.

is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).

Windows 98, Windows NT 4.0 Platform Note: You must call the Bind method before using AddMembership as the optionName parameter.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Shutdown(System.Net.Sockets.SocketShutdown)
member.summary: Disables sends and receives on a VirtualSocket.
member.param: The value specifying the operation that will no longer be allowed.
member.exception: An error occurs while closing the VirtualSocket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.para: Setting how to Send, specifies that subsequent calls to Send are not allowed. With TCP sockets, a FIN will be sent after all data is sent and acknowledged by the receiver.

Setting how to Receive, specifies that subsequent calls to Receive are not allowed. This has no effect on lower protocol layers. For TCP sockets, the connection is reset if data is waiting to be received or if more data arrives after the Socket is disabled. For UDP sockets, datagrams are accepted and queued.
Setting how to Both disables both sends and receives as described above.
To finish closing the Socket, a call to Close must be made after the call to Shutdown. You should not attempt to reuse the Socket.

member.summary: Gets the amount of data that has been received from the network and is available to be read.
member.value: The number of bytes of data that has been received from the network and are available to be read.
member.remarks: If you are using a Stream VirtualSocket type, the available data is generally the total amount of data queued on the current instance. If you are using a message-oriented VirtualSocket type such as Dgram, the available data is the first message in the input queue.
member.exception: An error occurs while accessing the VirtualSocket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Connected
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a VirtualSocket is connected to a remote resource.
member.value: true if the VirtualSocket is connected to a remote resource; otherwise, false.
member.remarks:
Gets the connection state of the VirtualSocket. This property will return the latest known state of the VirtualSocket. When it returns false, the VirtualSocket was either never connected, or no longer connected. When it returns true, the VirtualSocket was connected at the time of the last I/O operation.
Note There is no guarantee that the VirtualSocket is still Connected even though Connected returns true.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecureSocket.QueueRenegotiate
member.summary: Queues a renegotiation request.
member.exception: An operating system error occurs while accessing the SecureSocket.
member.remarks: Use the QueueRenegotiate function with caution. Some SSL/TLS clients or server do not support renegotiation. For instance, requesting a renegotiation in the middle of sending a HTTP request to a MS IIS server causes the connection to be shut down. Renegotiations should only be used when a small private key [512 bits] is used and the connection is active for a long period of time.

member.summary: Represents the security options that should be used when connecting to a secure server, or when accepting secure connections.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecureProtocol
member.summary: Specifies the type of security protocol that an instance of the class can use.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecureProtocol.None
member.summary: No security protocol will be used. The SecureSocket will act as a normal Socket.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecureProtocol.Ssl3
member.summary: SSLv3

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecureProtocol.Tls1
member.summary: TLS 1.0

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecureProtocol.Tls11
member.summary: TLS 1.1

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecureProtocol.Tls12
member.summary: TLS 1.2

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecurityFlags
member.summary: Specifies the different security flags that an instance of the class can use.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecurityFlags.Default
member.summary: No special behavior is required.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecurityFlags.MutualAuthentication
member.summary: Client authentication is required. This flag only has an effect on server sockets.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecurityFlags.DontSendEmptyRecord
member.summary: To avoid a certain CBC IV attack, the Security Library sends an empty message after the handshake and before the actual application payload. Unfortunately, some broken implementations do not support empty packets, so sending these empty packets can be turned off by specifying the DontSendEmptyRecord flag.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecurityFlags.IgnoreMaxProtocol
member.summary: Setting this flag will allow a client to issue a SSLv3.0 version number as latest version supported in the premaster secret, even when TLSv1.0 (version 3.1) was announced in the client hello. Normally this is forbidden to prevent version rollback attacks.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecurityFlags.DisableSessionResumption
member.summary: Setting this flag will allow a client to disable session resumption

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecurityFlags.DisableClientHelloExtension
member.summary: Setting this flag will allow a client to disable sending SSL Hello extensions unless TLS 1.2 is the minimum version specified. By default they are sent no matter what the version if TLS 1.2 is one of the versions. So not sent if the max TLS version is 1.1.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SecurityFlags.DisableExtendedMasterSecretSessionResumption
member.summary: Setting this flag disables the requirement that the extended master secret is needed for TLS session resumption.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.ConnectionEnd
member.summary: Specifies the different connection end values.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.ConnectionEnd.Server
member.summary: The is a server socket.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.ConnectionEnd.Client
member.summary: The is a client socket.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.FilterFlagAttribute
member.summary: Signifies that a flag enum value is only used for filtering other flags.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SslAlgorithms
member.summary: Specifies the different cipher suites and compression algorithms.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SslAlgorithms.SECURE_CIPHERS
member.summary: Cipher Suites that are currently considered secure. As a convenience, this value also specifies NULL compression.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SslAlgorithms.ALL_CIPHERS
member.summary: All valid ciphers - excludes fallback and reneg!

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SslAlgorithms.TLS_FALLBACK_SCSV
member.summary: Signals client support for fallback

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SslAlgorithms.TLS_EMPTY_RENEGOTIATION_INFO_SCSV
member.summary: Signals support for renegotation

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.SslAlgorithms.NULL_COMPRESSION
member.summary: No compression. This value must always be specified; it is currently the only supported compression algorithm.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.CredentialVerification
member.summary: Specifies the method used to verify the remote credential.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.CredentialVerification.Manual
member.summary: The remote certificate will be manually verified. When an incoming connection is accepted, the SecureSocket will raise a CertVerification event. This is the recommended credential verification method.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.CredentialVerification.Auto
member.summary: The remote certificate will be automatically verified by the crypto API.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Ssl.CredentialVerification.AutoWithoutCName
member.summary: The remote certificate will be automatically verified by the crypto API, but the common name of the server will not be checked.

T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.KnownHostsManager
member.summary: Holds details of the known hosts and their public keys.

remarks.para: The known_hosts file contains a list of approved servers and their public keys. Setting to instructs the client to use this list to validate the servers that it connects to. Setting ServerValidation to is similar, however the server name is ignored in the validation process.
A single line in a known_hosts file looks like this:

edtmobile,10.0.0.3 ssh-rsa AAAAB3NzaC1yc2EAAAABIwAAAIEAt60CtjBMxiOO qgqfFtKZHY3g99uZpuh5E143FTO4dw+EHWNKemoWq59FMFMIZfSLyUpWmsjVT3PP1bc zOXP1OSn967kxLB/w7Xr84B1ZrTLwuR/ilq73HpgO7A8pdEJN7ybprzhs5CBEgaLQo2 pOxfqRYyc8TO2ADnZ1WwtjW48=

The first field is the hostname, i.e. the SSH server. The IP address is also listed - a number of comma separated hostnames and IP addresses can be listed. The second field is the applicable public key algorithm -"ssh-rsa" (for RSA key pairs) or "ssh-dss" (for DSA key pairs). The third field is the public key encoded using base 64.

The known_hosts file normally consists of multiple lines, one for each of the hosts that the client may wish to connect to. It is quite typical for a host to have entries in two lines, so that both RSA and DSA public keys can be listed.

The path of the known_hosts file should be assigned to the property to load the known hosts in that file into the manager. If another known_hosts file is subsequently assigned to this property, its contents will be added to the current list of known hosts. Use to clear the current list.

Server public keys can also be maintained in their own key file and be used for server validation without adding them to the known_hosts file. The KnownHostsManager supports explicitly adding server public keys in this manner, via .
Use to write the current contents of the known hosts lists to a file. If hosts are loaded via the and also by , the combined list can be merged into one known_hosts file by using .

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.KnownHostsManager.AddKnownHost(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Add a hostname/public key pair to the known hosts data.
member.remarks:
Server public keys can also be maintained in their own key file and be used for server validation without adding them to the known_hosts file using this method. SSH public key files have two standard formats - OpenSSH and SECSH. Both these public key formats are supported. Formats can be recognized by their first line as shown below:
OpenSSH (DSA) OpenSSH format as a DSA public key. The first line begins with "ssh-dss AAAAB3NzaC1kc3MAA ...".
OpenSSH (RSA) OpenSSH format as a DSA public key. The first line begins with "ssh-rsa AAAAB3NzaC1yc2EAA ...".
SECSH SECSH format. The first line begins with "---- BEGIN SSH2 PUBLIC KEY ----"
You can convert between OpenSSH and SECSH formats using OpenSSH's ssh-keygen utility (which by default generates OpenSSH keys).
member.param: hostname
public key file for host

member.summary: Name of file containing the list of known hosts and their public keys that was most recently loaded.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.KnownHostsManager.NumHosts
member.summary: Number of known hosts names and IP addresses that have been loaded.
member.remarks: This count distinguishes between the various names or IP addresses that a host may have. If a host is represented by several names or IP addresses, it will be counted that many times in the overall count. So if a host has been loaded with the name "edtmobile" and also "192.168.19.64", it will be counted twice in the overall count.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.PEMReader.GetUnpadded(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Unfortunately our PEMWriter uses zeros rather than no padding, which is how it should be done. No padding tells you how much padding there is by setting the padding byte to the number of padded bytes. Fortunately, there is never zero padding on the no padding scheme, because if the data length fits the block size, we add another full block of padding.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SFTPSubsystem
member.summary: Implements a client SFTP subsystem on top of the SSH channel
member.remarks:
SFTP messages are sent to the server as SSH_MSG_CHANNEL_DATA messages. Each consists of:
byte SSH_MSG_CHANNEL_DATA uint32 recipient channel string data
Note that a string itself is compromised of a uint32 containing its length (number of bytes that follow) and zero (= empty string) or more bytes that are the value of the string.
All SFTP packets (which compromise the data string) transmitted over the secure connection are of the following format:
uint32 length byte type uint32 request-id ... type specific fields ...
EXCEPT for the INIT and VERSION messages which omit the request-id
This is the data portion of the SSH_MSG_CHANNEL_DATA message

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SFTPSubsystem.MSG_OVERHEAD
member.summary: This is the max overhead (a guess!) that an FXP msg incurs when it is layered on top of an SSH_CHANNEL_DATA message

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Util.GetOpt
member.summary: C# equivalent of Unix getopt().
member.remarks:
Only partially implemented, just enough so it is useful internally.
Short option are of the form -a -b -c or equivalently -abc for options with no arguments, or -a foo -b foo for arguments, or even -afoo -bfoo.
Arguments may be optional or required. If optional, they must be supplied as -afoo rather than -a foo.
The options are specified by a string containing each option char. If a character is followed by a single colon, then that option has a required argument. If the character is followed by two colons, then that option has an argument that is not required. No colon means no argument.
member.author: Bruce Blackshaw

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Util.Debug.Lock
member.summary: Utility class for helping to debug deadlocks caused by lock synchronization.
member.remarks: When run in debug mode it will print logging information before entering and after leaving each lock-block. To use, replace all occurrances of lock(xyz) with using(new LoggingLock(xyz)).

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Util.Debug.MemoryAppender

member.remarks: This appender keeps only the past lines in memory. They may be accessed at any time using the property. It is useful for debugging problems where timing is critical (e.g. deadlocks).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Util.License.LicenseReader.CalcRegExpiryDateNew(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Returns the expiry date encoded into the given key
member.remarks: Returns the expiry date encoded into the given key, provided that the name matches the key. If the name doesn't match the key or if the key is invalid in some way, then an invalid date is returned.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Util.Socks.Socks4Context
member.summary: Socks4Context holds information about making SOCKS4 connections.

remarks.para:
At a minimum the following properties must be set:
Property Description
ProxyAddress Address to be used to connect to the proxy.
ProxyPort Port to be used to connect to the proxy (defaults to 1080).
UserName User-name to be used for validation on the proxy.

The following properties should be used in cases where problems establishing SOCKS connections are encountered:
Property Description
PublicProxyAddress Address that the proxy server presents to the "outside" network.
UseClientNameResolution Use SOCKS4A feature of requesting that the proxy should resolve host-names.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Util.Socks.SocksContext.ProxyAddress
member.summary: Address to be used to connect to the proxy.
member.remarks: Proxies often have more than one address. This address should be the one that the client must use to connect to it.

member.summary: Port to be used to connect to the proxy.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Util.Socks.SocksContext.PublicProxyAddress
member.summary: Address that the proxy server presents to the "outside" network.

remarks.para: This is the address that systems that are being connected to through the proxy will see.

SOCKS servers usually provide this address to the client as SOCKS connections to be made, so it's usually unnecessary to set this property. In some instances however, when the server does not provide this address it may be necessary to set this property.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Util.Socks.Socks4Context.UseClientNameResolution
member.summary: Use SOCKS4A feature of requesting that the proxy should resolve host-names.
member.remarks: The SOCKS4 protocol requires host-names to be resolved on the client-side. In some cases this is not feasible, so SOCKS4A introduced an extension which allowed name-resolution to be performed on the proxy instead. If this flag is set then the SOCKS4A extension will be employed thus preventing the attempt to resolve host-names on the client. The default is false.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Util.Socks.Socks5Context
member.summary: Socks5Context holds information about making SOCKS5 connections.

remarks.para:
At a minimum the following properties must be set:
Property Description
ProxyAddress Address to be used to connect to the proxy.
ProxyPort Defaults to 1080 - Port to be used to connect to the proxy.
UserName User-name to be used for validation on the proxy.
Authentication Methods At least one authentication method must be provided.

The SOCKS5 standard specifies three authentications methods. Currently, GSSAPI is not supported. If it is required please request it from EDT support.
Authentication Method Description
Null Performs no authentication.
Username/Password Uses a plain-text user-name/password combination.
GSSAPI (Currently not supported) Uses the Generic Security Services Application Program Interface (GSS-API) to communicate with system-level security services (SSPI on Windows) to authenticate the user.

member.remarks: Before the context can be used, the proxy-address and one or more authentication methods must be set using the AuthMethods property.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Util.Socks.Socks5Context.AuthMethods
member.summary: Collection of authentication methods to be used.

remarks.para: Before the context can be used, one or more authentication methods must be set using the AuthMethods property.

The SOCKS5 standard specifies three authentications methods. Currently, GSSAPI is not supported. If it is required please request it from EDT support.
Authentication Method Description
Null Performs no authentication.
Username/Password Uses a plain-text user-name/password combination.
GSSAPI (Currently not supported) Uses the Generic Security Services Application Program Interface (GSS-API) to communicate with system-level security services (SSPI on Windows) to authenticate the user.
